3.7.3 Control and Management of Hazardous Waste
Do not dispose of hazardous waste on Government property. Do not discharge
any waste to a sanitary sewer, storm drain, or to surface waters or conduct
waste treatment or disposal on Government property without written approval
of the CO. Provide the documentation required in this subsection in the
Hazardous Waste/Debris Management Report of the Environmental Records
Binder.
3.7.3.1 Hazardous Waste/Debris Management
a. Prepare a Hazardous Waste/Debris Management Report that identifies
the hazardous waste or debris, and the quantities of each, that were
generated by construction activities. Include a documented waste
determination for resultant waste streams. Identify, label, handle,
store, and dispose of hazardous waste or debris in accordance with
Federal, State, and local regulations, including 40 CFR 261, 40 CFR 262,
and 40 CFR 268. Include the Hazardous Waste/Debris Management Report
in the Environmental Records Binder.
b. Manage hazardous waste in accordance with the approved EPP. Store
hazardous wastes in approved containers in accordance with 49 CFR 173.
Hazardous waste generated within the confines of Government facilities
is identified as being generated by the Government. Do not bring
hazardous waste onto Government property.
3.7.3.2 Hazardous Waste Disposal
The following applies to disposal of any hazardous waste:
a. Use, or propose for use, materials which may be considered
environmentally friendly in that waste from such materials is not
regulated as a hazardous waste or is not considered harmful to the
environment.
b. Documentation for analysis, sampling, transportation, and disposal
of all hazardous waste generated during this Contract must be in
accordance with 40 CFR 260 - 40 CFR 262.
c. Remove all Contractor-generated hazardous wastes from the project
for proper disposal within 90 days of waste generation or at the
completion of on-site work. Package, label, and mark all hazardous
waste in accordance with 49 CFR 172 and 40 CFR 262. Store all
hazardous waste in accordance with 40 CFR 262.
d. Transportation of Contractor hazardous material must be in
accordance with 49 CFR 171, 49 CFR 172, and 49 CFR 173.
e. Use the Contractor's Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
identification number to dispose of all hazardous waste generated by
the Contractor and its subcontractors under this Contract. This is
construed to mean all hazardous waste the Contractor or subcontractors
generate from materials brought on the site for the purpose of
performing work under the terms of the Contract.
f. The Government will dispose of all hazardous waste generated from
Government-owned facilities on the project. This is construed to mean
hazardous wastes generated from the repair, demolition, or removal of
any existing materials and buildings from the Government facilities and

is not intended to include any wastes generated by the Contractor in

g. The GQAR will notify the project Environmental Compliance

project ECC will ensure that the wastes are labeled correctly. The
GQAR will notify the project ECC when waste containers are full. The

3.7.3.3 Universal Waste Management
a. Manage universal waste in accordance with 40 CFR 273 and Federal,
State, and local requirements.
b. Mercury is prohibited in the construction of this facility, unless
specified otherwise, and with the exception of mercury vapor lamps and
fluorescent lamps. Dumping of mercury-containing materials and devices
such as mercury vapor lamps, fluorescent lamps, or mercury switches in
rubbish containers is prohibited. Remove without breaking, pack to
prevent breakage, and transport out of the activity in an unbroken
condition for disposal as directed.
3.7.3.4 Electronics End-of-Life Management
Recycle or dispose of electronics waste, including, but not limited to,
used electronic devices such computers, monitors, hard-copy devices,
televisions, mobile devices, in accordance with 40 CFR 260-262, State, and
local requirements.
3.7.4 Releases/Spills of Oil and Hazardous Substances
Exercise due diligence to prevent, contain, and respond to spills of
hazardous material, hazardous substances, hazardous waste, sewage,
regulated gas, petroleum, lubrication oil, and other substances regulated
in accordance with 40 CFR 300. Maintain spill cleanup equipment and
materials at the work site. In the event of a spill, take prompt,
effective action to stop, contain, curtail, or otherwise limit the amount,
duration, and severity of the spill/release.
3.7.5 Mercury Materials
a. Immediately report to the Environmental Compliance Coordinator and
the CO instances of breakage or mercury spillage. Clean mercury spill
area to the satisfaction of the CO.

b. Do not recycle a mercury spill cleanup; manage it as a hazardous

3.7.6 Wastewater
3.7.6.1 Treatment
Do not allow wastewater from construction activities, such as onsite
material processing, concrete curing, foundation and concrete clean-up,
water used in concrete trucks, and forms to enter waterways or to be
discharged prior to being treated to remove pollutants. Dispose of the
construction-related waste water by collecting and placing it in a drum or
tank where suspended material can be settled out or the water can evaporate
to separate pollutants from the water. The site for the drum or tank must
be coordinated and approved with the CO. The residue left in the drum or
tank, prior to completion of the project must be removed, tested, and
disposed of off Government property in accordance with Federal, State, and
local laws and regulations.
3.7.6.2 Sanitary Sewer Discharge
Discharges to sanitary sewers are not allowed unless the Contractor has
obtained all applicable permits for those discharges.
3.7.6.3 Surface Discharge
Surface discharge of wastewater to land or waterways is not permitted
unless the Contractor has obtained all applicable NPDES permits for that
discharge.
3.7.6.4 Land Application
Do not allow sheeting action, soil erosion, discharge into storm sewers,
discharge into defined drainage areas, or discharge into the "waters of the
United States". Comply with Federal, State, and local laws and regulations.
3.8 HAZARDOUS MATERIAL MANAGEMENT
Include hazardous material control procedures in the Safety Plan, in
accordance with Section 01 35 26.00 25, GOVERNMENTAL SAFETY REQUIREMENTS.
Address procedures and proper handling of hazardous materials, including
the appropriate transportation requirements. Do not bring hazardous
material onto Government property that does not directly relate to
requirements for the performance of this Contract. Typical materials
requiring SDS and quantity reporting include, but are not limited to, oil
and latex based painting and caulking products, solvents, adhesives,
aerosol, and petroleum products. Use hazardous materials in a manner that
minimizes the amount of hazardous waste generated. Containers of hazardous
materials must have National Fire Protection Association labels or their
equivalent. Certify that hazardous materials removed from the site do not
meet the definition of hazardous waste, in accordance with 40 CFR 261.

3.10 PETROLEUM, OILS, AND LUBRICANTS (POLs) STORAGE AND FUELING
Utilize environmentally acceptable lubricants including hydraulic fluid as
in accordance with EPA 800-R-11-002 when operating equipment below Ordinary
High Water and work over water. Store POL products in a manner that
affords the maximum protection against spills into the environment. Fuel
equipment and motor vehicles in a manner that affords the maximum
protection against spills into the environment. Use secondary
containments, dikes, curbs, and other barriers, to prevent POL products
from spilling and entering the ground, storm or sewer drains, stormwater
ditches or canals, or navigable waters of the United States. Describe in
the EPP (see Paragraph ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION PLAN) how POL tanks and
containers must be stored, managed, and inspected and what protections must
be provided.
a. Inspect all equipment, vehicles, and power tools for fluid leaks
before they arrive onto the project site.
b. Before operation within 150 feet of any body of water, and as often
as necessary during operation, thoroughly clean all equipment,
vehicles, and power tools to keep them free of external fluids and
grease and to prevent leaks and spills from entering the water.
c. Maintain and protect generators, cranes, or other stationary heavy
equipment operated within 150 feet of any waterbody as necessary to
prevent leaks and spills from entering the water.
3.10.1 Used Oil Management
Manage used oil generated on site in accordance with 40 CFR 279. Determine
if any used oil generated while onsite exhibits a characteristic of
hazardous waste. Used oil containing 1,000 parts per million of solvents
is considered a hazardous waste and disposed of at the Contractor's
expense. Used oil mixed with a hazardous waste is also considered a
hazardous waste. Dispose in accordance with Paragraph HAZARDOUS WASTE
DISPOSAL.
3.10.2 Oil Storage Including Fuel Tanks
a. Contractor will not store fuel in containers over five gallons on
the work site.Provide secondary containment and overfill protection for
POL storage tanks and refueling onsite. Use drip pans during oil
transfer operations. Cover tanks and drip pans during inclement
weather. Provide procedures and equipment to prevent overfilling of
tanks.
b. Inspect all all vehicles for oil leaks when arriving onsite and
remove any vehicle found to have oil, fuel, or hydraulic leaks from the
worksite. Contractor will place containment under any equipment
awaiting removal for oil leaks. Contractor will maintain containment
under all fixed machinery including generators and light plants.
Contractor will keep records of these inspections and include them
weekly in their Contractor Quality Control Report.
c. Monitor and remove any rainwater that accumulates in open
containment pans, dikes, or berms. Inspect the accumulated rainwater
prior to draining from a containment dike to the environment, to
SECTION 01 57 19.00 25 Page 29
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
determine there is no oil sheen present. If oil sheen is present,
treat and dispose of accumulated rainwater in an

3.11 INADVERTENT DISCOVERY OF PETROLEUM-CONTAMINATED SOIL OR HAZARDOUS
WASTES
If petroleum-contaminated soil, or suspected hazardous waste is found

3.12 NOISE CONTROL
3.12.1 General
Keep construction activities under surveillance and control to minimize
environmental damage by noise. Noise control and noise levels must conform
to requirements set forth in the appropriate regulations, including
EM 385-1-1 Section 05.C, 29 CFR 1926.52, and 29 CFR 1926.101. The most
conservative requirement will govern.
3.12.2 Noise Limitations
Follow local noise requirements. In the absence of local requirements, the
noise levels, as measured from the nearest dwelling, must not exceed 50
decibels during the hours from 2200 hours to 0700 hours.
3.13 POST CONSTRUCTION CLEANUP
Clean up areas used for construction. Unless otherwise instructed in
writing by the CO, remove traces of temporary construction facilities such
as haul roads, work area, structures, foundations of temporary structures,
stockpiles of excess or waste materials, and other vestiges of construction
prior to final acceptance of the work. Grade parking area and similar
temporarily used areas to conform with surrounding contours.

PART 1 GENERAL
1.1 GENERAL INFORMATION
a. The design drawings are based on topographic surveys and LIDAR data
described on the Survey Narrative, however the extent and coverage of
the data collected was limited by deep, moving water and sediments that
covered the bedrock surface. The Government generally considers the
pre-construction data to be insufficient for Quality Assurance and
Quality control during construction and additional data is necessary.
b. Existing Bedrock Survey No. 1: The bedrock and existing
Roller-Compacted Concrete (RCC) surface of the existing spillway (full
width) extending from the limits of the first raise to limits of the
second and beyond to the full extent of the spillway width extending in
the down stream direction (at least)to the dashed line on C-007 with a
label "NO DIVERSION AREA". This will require a survey at different
times depending on the Contractor's dewatering plan. Construction
activities executed under this Contract will have access to the bedrock
surface afforded by dewatering and foundation preparation.
c. RCC Footprint Survey No.2: The second survey will cover the entire
prepared surface for the RCC and plunge pool.
d. Top of RCC Survey No.3: The third survey will define the breaklines
and grades for the completed RCC and be used for As-Built drawing
submittals by Contractor specified in Section 01 78 39.10 25 AS-BUILT
DRAWINGS. It will also be used for quantity calculations and payment.
e. Topographic surveys and maps of the bedrock are required to verify
the elevations for Quality Assurance, Quality Control, and quantity
calculations. Contractor to submit electronic survey data for use by
the Government.
f. The Attachment A9, Cut and Fill Volume Report provides estimated
volume of cut and fill.

basic designation only.

PART 2 PRODUCTS
2.1 DESCRIPTION
This Section specifies the gathering of research documents, performance of
a topographic survey, and preparation of a topographic survey map.
2.2 DEFINITIONS
a. Professional Land Surveyor: One who possesses a valid state license
as a "Professional Land Surveyor" from the state in which they practice.
b. Professional Civil Engineer: One who possesses a valid state license
as a "Professional Civil Engineer" from the state in which they
practice. For this Section, the term "surveyor" must also include
Professional Civil Engineers authorized to practice Land Surveying
under the laws of the state in which they practice.
c. Break Lines: Breaklines are a series of points with x, y, z
coordinates that are connected to one another by linear segments.
These segments are represented by polylines, lines or shapes in AutoCAD.
Two or more points are required to define a breakline. Breaklines
represent discontinuities in the ground surface being surveyed such as
an abrupt change in slope, ridges, ditches, top edges of concrete
walls, and front and back of wall where earth and concrete meet.
Breaklines can also represent the limits of riprap, gravel surfacing,
cobble armor, edges of pavement, and edges of concrete, etc. When
triangulating a surface that contains breakline data, triangles are
formed so that no triangle side crosses a breakline segment. The
breakline holds a linear relationship that might otherwise be removed
during triangulation. Breaklines should not cross one another unless
they have a crossing point with the same x, y and z (coordinate).
d. Random Points: Represent randomly occurring points with x,y,z
coordinates. Random points are collected because they are points that
generally define the surface and can be uniformly or non-uniformly
spaced. Random points are referred to as regular points, spots
elevation or ground shots. Random points are also surveyed at high and
low spots in the topography.
e. Sufficient Density: Data collection for breaklines or random points
SECTION 01 71 23.16 25 Page 3
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
of survey that capture all necessary surface topography. Random and
breakline points must be surveyed at intervals to meet the map accuracy
standards to create a 1"=30' map and 1' contour interval. Follow the
accuracy standards for the precise end of the range for the Grading and
Excavation plan category in Table 6-1 EM 1110-1-1005, page 6-25
(Military Facilities).
2.3 SURVEY AND MAPPING PLAN
Provide a Survey and Mapping Plan that outlines the designated personnel,
tools, and methods which will be used to perform the topographic surveys
and mapping specified in this Section. The Contracting Officer (CO) will
confirm the required contour interval and scale of mapping as it affects
the accuracy of any subsequent volume computations.
PART 3 EXECUTION
3.1 GENERAL
a. Perform an Existing Bedrock Survey as specified below.
b. Perform a Plunge Pool and Channel Excavation Survey as specified
below.
c. All surveys must be performed by a licensed surveyor or civil
engineer registered in the State of Washington.
d. The surveyor must research available public records for all mapping,
monumentation, plats, Governmental surveys etc., that may pertain to
the construction site.
e. Collect topographic data in accordance with EM 1110-1-1000 and
EM 1110-1-1005.
f. Survey must meet Class I Mapping according to American Society for
Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing (ASPRS) as outlined in EM 1110-1-1000
or,
g. Survey must meet the standard for General Construction Site Plan
Feature and Topo Detail as outlined in EM 1110-1-1000. For example the
feature location tolerance must be 100 mm with 3rd order control.
h. Digital CADD files with raw data in ASCII Text and Excel Spreadsheet
(Excel 2000 Version 9 or later)files, processed elevation surface TIN,
and contours readable in AutoCAD Civil 3D format.
i. All other CADD specifications requirements according to Section
01 78 39.10 25 AS-BUILT DRAWINGS.
3.2 EXISTING BEDROCK SURVEY
3.2.1 General
A topographic survey and map of the bedrock is required to verify the
elevations of existing bedrock for Quality Assurance, Quality Control, and
quantity calculations. Contractor to submit Electronic Survey Data Files
for use by the Government.
SECTION 01 71 23.16 25 Page 4
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
3.2.2 Survey of Existing Bedrock
a. Collect topographic data for bedrock surface after all foundation
preparation has been completed. The scope of bedrock cleaning is
limited to the RCC placement area, however, the bedrock survey should
include all bedrock within the existing spillway channel from the
downstream limits of the first spillway raise to the limits of this
second RCC raise and beyond to the limits of the cleared vegetation
area on C-005. Existing RCC must be prepared and cleaned prior to the
bedrock survey to ensure extents are captured.
b. The data must be of sufficient density and accuracy to compute
volumes of roller-compacted concrete (RCC) placed for the spillway
raise.
c. It is anticipated that there will be enough exposed bedrock in the
channel outside the RCC placement area that a reasonable topographic
surface can be created and still meet the mapping standards specified.
If substantial sediment deposits exist on the bedrock, they must be
illustrated on the prepared map.
d. Collect an Orthophoto of the prepared bedrock surface for each
de-watered area of the RCC footprint, understanding that this will
require two photos covering the entire spillway limits of construction
shown on the plans and at least 100 feet beyond. The Contract drawings
show an orthophoto of the spillway channel during the first spillway
raise that does not meet this specification because the surface was not
fully prepared at the time of the photo collection.
3.3 RCC FOOTPRINT SURVEY
A survey and map of the final prepared surface for the RCC including the
plunge pool excavation is required to verify the elevations for Quality
Assurance, Quality Control, and quantity calculations. Contractor to
submit Electronic Survey Data Files for use by the Government. The data
must be of sufficient density and accuracy with appropriate break lines to
compute volumes of rock excavation.
3.4 TOP OF RCC SURVEY
Collect topographic data for the top of RCC The data must be of sufficient
density and accuracy with appropriate break lines to compute volumes of RCC
placed. This is an as-built survey and will extend 15 feet beyond the RCC
placed. Contractor to submit Electronic Survey Data Files for use by the
Government.
3.5 PROJECT DATUM
The Government will provide all known bench marks and coordinates required
to perform the topographic surveys in the project datum. The project datum
is described in the Survey Narrative on the Contract plans sheet G-002.
3.6 QUANTITIES
Volume calculations must be based upon the triangle volume method. At
least two DTMs are necessary to calculate a quantity; the initial and final
survey. Provide Quantities of rock excavated and RCC placed in a report
similar to that attached which was the basis for the estimated quantities
in the bid schedule.
SECTION 01 71 23.16 25 Page 5
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
3.7 SURVEY NARRATIVE
Prepare a Survey Narrative and Survey Plan to accompany the surveys
completed under this Contract and submit as part of the requirements under
Section 01 78 39.10 25 AS-BUILT DRAWINGS. The survey narrative and survey
plan must be stamped by a professional land surveyor and be prepared in
similar format as that provided with the Contract drawings G-002 and G-003.

SECTION 01 74 19.00 25
CONSTRUCTION WASTE MANAGEMENT AND DISPOSAL
PART 1 GENERAL
1.1 DEFINITIONS
1.1.1 Co-mingle
The practice of placing unrelated materials together in a single container,
usually for benefits of convenience and speed.
1.1.2 Construction Waste
Waste generated by construction activities, such as scrap materials,
damaged or spoiled materials, temporary and expendable construction
materials, and other waste generated by the workforce during construction
activities.
1.1.3 Demolition Debris/Waste
Waste generated from demolition activities, including minor incidental
demolition waste materials generated as a result of intentional dismantling
of all or portions of a building, to include clearing of building contents
that have been destroyed or damaged.
1.1.4 Disposal
Depositing waste in a solid waste disposal facility, usually a managed
landfill or incinerator, regulated in the US under the Resource
Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA).
1.1.5 Diversion
The practice of diverting waste from disposal in a landfill or incinerator,
by means of eliminating or minimizing waste, or reuse of materials.
1.1.6 Final Construction Waste Diversion Report
A written assertion by a material recovery facility operator identifying
constituent materials diverted from disposal, usually including summary
tabulations of materials, weight in short-ton.
1.1.7 Recycling
The series of activities, including collection, separation, and processing,
by which products or other materials are diverted from the solid waste
stream for use in the form of raw materials in the manufacture of new
products sold or distributed in commerce, or the reuse of such materials as
substitutes for goods made of virgin materials, other than fuel.
1.1.8 Reuse
The use of a product or materials again for the same purpose, in its
original form or with little enhancement or change.
SECTION 01 74 19.00 25 Page 3
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
1.1.9 Salvage
Usable, salable items derived from buildings undergoing demolition or
deconstruction, parts from vehicles, machinery, other equipment, or other
components.
1.1.10 Source Separation
The practice of administering and implementing a management strategy to
identify and segregate unrelated waste at the first opportunity.
1.2 CONSTRUCTION WASTE (INCLUDES DEMOLITION DEBRIS/WASTE)
Divert a minimum of 60 percent by weight of the project construction waste
and demolition debris/waste from the landfill or incinerator. Follow
applicable industry standards in the management of waste. Apply sound
environmental principles in the management of waste.
a. Practice efficient waste management when sizing, cutting, and
installing products and materials and
b. Use all reasonable means to divert construction waste and demolition
debris/waste from landfills and incinerators and to facilitate the
recycling or reuse of excess construction materials.
1.3 CONSTRUCTION WASTE MANAGEMENT
Implement a Construction Waste Management Program for the project.
Establish a process for clear tracking, and documentation of construction
waste and demolition debris/waste.
1.3.1 Implementation of Construction Waste Management Program
Develop and document how the Construction Waste Management Program will be
implemented in a Construction Waste Management Plan. Submit a Construction
Waste Management Plan to the Contracting Officer (CO) for approval.
Construction waste and demolition debris/waste materials include un-used
construction materials not incorporated in the final work, as well as
demolition debris/waste materials from demolition activities or
deconstruction activities. In the management of waste, consider the
availability of viable markets, the condition of materials, the ability to
provide material in suitable condition and in a quantity acceptable to
available markets, and time constraints imposed by internal project
completion mandates.
1.3.2 Oversight
The Quality Control Manager, as specified in Section 01 45 00.00 25 QUALITY
CONTROL, is responsible for overseeing and documenting results from
executing the Construction Waste Management Plan for the project.
1.3.3 Special Instructions
Provide on-site instruction of appropriate separation, handling, recycling,
salvage, reuse, and return methods to be used by all parties at the
appropriate stages of the projects. Designation of single source
separating or commingling will be clearly marked on the containers.
SECTION 01 74 19.00 25 Page 4
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
1.3.4 Waste Streams
Delineate waste streams and characterization, including estimated material
types and quantities of waste, in the Construction Waste Management Plan.
Manage all waste streams associated with the project. Typical waste
streams are listed below. Include additional waste steams not listed:
a. Land Clearing Debris
b. Asphalt
c. Masonry and CMU
d. Concrete
e. Metals (Includes, but is not limited to, banding, stud trim,
ductwork, piping, rebar, roofing, other trim, steel, iron, galvanized,
stainless steel, aluminum, copper, zinc, bronze.)
f. Wood (nails and staples allowed)
g. Glass
h. Paper
i. Plastics (PET, HDPE,PVC,LDPE,PP,PS, Other)
j. Gypsum
k. Non-hazardous paint and paint cans
l. Carpet
m. Ceiling Tiles
n. Insulation
o. Beverage Containers

Government approval is required for submittals with a "G". Submittals not
having a "G" classification are for information only. Submit the following
in accordance with Section 01 33 00 SUBMITTAL PROCEDURES:
SD-01 Preconstruction Submittals
Construction Waste Management Plan; G
SD-06 Test Reports
Quarterly Reports
Annual Report
SD-11 Closeout Submittals
Final Construction Waste Diversion Report; G
SECTION 01 74 19.00 25 Page 5
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
1.5 MEETINGS
a. Conduct Construction Waste Management meetings. After award of the
Contract and prior to commencement of work, schedule and conduct a
meeting with the CO to discuss the proposed Construction Waste
Management Plan and to develop a mutual understanding relative to the
management of the Construction Waste Management Program and how waste
diversion requirements will be met.
b. At a minimum, discuss and document waste management goals at
following meetings:
(1) Preconstruction meeting.
(2) Preparatory meetings.
(3) Regular coordination meetings.
(4) Safety Meetings.
1.6 CONSTRUCTION WASTE MANAGEMENT PLAN (CWMP)
a. Submit Construction Waste Management Plan as part of the PSMP.
Approval of the CWMP is required prior to the start of on-site work.
Manage demolition debris/waste or deconstruction materials in
accordance with the approved construction waste management plan.
b. An approved CWMP will not relieve the Contractor of responsibility
for compliance with applicable environmental regulations or meeting
project cumulative waste diversion requirement. Ensure all
subcontractors receive a copy of the approved Construction Waste
Management Plan. The plan demonstrates how to meet the project waste
diversion requirement. Also, include the following in the plan:
(1) Identify the names of individuals responsible for waste
management and waste management tracking, along with roles and
responsibilities on the project.
(2) Actions that will be taken to reduce solid waste generation,
including coordination with subcontractors to ensure awareness and
participation.
(3) Description of the regular meetings to be held to address
waste management.
(4) Description of the specific approaches to be used in
recycling/reuse of the various materials generated, including the
areas on site and equipment to be used for processing, sorting,
and temporary storage of materials.
(5) Name of landfill and incinerator to be used.
(6) Identification of local and regional re-use programs,
including non-profit organizations such as schools, local housing
agencies, and organization that accept used materials such as
material exchange networks and resale stores. Include the name,
location, phone number for each re-use facility identified, and
provide a copy of the permit or license for each facility.
SECTION 01 74 19.00 25 Page 6
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
(7) List of specific materials, by type and quantity, that will be
salvaged for resale, salvaged and reused on the current project,
salvaged and stored for reuse on a future project, or recycled.
Identify the recycling facilities by name, address, and phone
number.
(8) Identification of materials that cannot be recycled or reused
with an explanation or justification, to be approved by the CO.
(9) Description of the means by which materials identified in item
(g) above will be protected from contamination.
(10) Description of the means of transportation of the recyclable
materials (whether materials will be site-separated and
self-hauled to designated centers, or whether mixed materials will
be collected by a waste hauler and removed from the site).
(11) Copy of training plan for subcontractors and other services
to prevent contamination by co-mingling materials identified for
diversion and waste materials.
1.7 RECORDS (DOCUMENTATION)
1.7.1 General
Maintain records to document the types and quantities of waste generated
and diverted though re-use, recycling and sale to third parties; through
disposal to a landfill or incinerator facility. Provide explanations for
materials not recycled, reused or sold. Collect and retain manifests,
weight tickets, sales receipts, and invoices specifically identifying
diverted project waste materials or disposed materials.
1.7.2 Accumulated
Maintain a running record of materials generated and diverted from landfill
disposal, including accumulated diversion rates for the project. Make
records available to the CO during construction or incidental demolition
activities. Provide a copy of the diversion records to the CO upon
completion of the construction, incidental demolitions or minor
deconstruction activities.
1.8 REPORTS
1.8.1 General
Maintain current construction waste diversion information on site for
periodic inspection by the CO. Include in the quarterly reports, annual
reports and final reports: the project name, Contract information,
information for waste generated, diverted and disposed of for the current
reporting period and show cumulative totals for the project. Reports must
identify quantifies of waste by type and disposal method. Also include in
each report, supporting documentation to include manifests, weigh tickets,
receipts, and invoices specifically identifying the project and waste
material type and weighted sum.
1.8.2 Quarterly Reporting
Provide cumulative reports at the end of each quarter (December, March,
June, and September, corresponding with the federal fiscal year for
SECTION 01 74 19.00 25 Page 7
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
reporting purposes). Submit quarterly reports not later than 15 calendar
days after the preceding quarter has ended. See Attachment A11 for an
example report.
1.8.3 Annual Reporting
Provide a cumulative construction waste diversion report annually. Submit
annual report not later than 30 calendar days after the preceding fourth
quarter has ended.
1.9 FINAL CONSTRUCTION WASTE DIVERSION REPORT
A Final Construction Waste Diversion Report is required at the end of the
project. Provide Final Construction Waste Diversion Report within 90
calendar days of final Construction physical completion.
1.10 COLLECTION
a. Collect, store, protect, and handle reusable and recyclable
materials at the site in a manner which prevents contamination, and
provides protection from the elements to preserve their usefulness and
monetary value. Provide receptacles and storage areas designated
specifically for recyclable and reusable materials and label them
clearly and appropriately to prevent contamination from other waste
materials. Keep receptacles or storage areas neat and clean.
b. Separate materials by one of the following methods described herein:
1.10.1 Source Separation Method
Separate waste products and materials that are recyclable from trash and
sort as described below into appropriately marked separate containers and
then transport to the respective recycling facility for further
processing. Deliver materials in accordance with recycling or reuse
facility requirements (e.g., free of dirt, adhesives, solvents, petroleum
contamination, and other substances deleterious to the recycling process).
Separate materials into the category types as defined in the Construction
Waste Management Plan.
1.10.2 Co-Mingled Method
Place waste products and recyclable materials into a single container and
then transport to an authorized recycling facility, which meets all
applicable requirements to accept and dispose of recyclable materials in
accordance with all applicable local, state and federal regulations. The
Co-mingled materials must be sorted and processed in accordance with the
approved Construction Waste Management Plan.
1.10.3 Other Methods
Other methods proposed by the Contractor may be used when approved by the
CO.
1.11 DISPOSAL
Control accumulation of waste materials and trash. Recycle or dispose of
collected materials off-site at intervals approved by the CO and in
compliance with waste management procedures as described in the waste
management plan. Except as otherwise specified in other sections of the
SECTION 01 74 19.00 25 Page 8
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
specifications, dispose of in accordance with the following:
1.11.1 Reuse
Give first consideration to reusing construction and demolition materials
as a disposition strategy. Recover for reuse materials, products, and
components as described in the approved Construction Waste Management
Plan. Coordinate with the CO to identify onsite reuse opportunities or
material sales or donation available through Government resale or donation
programs. Sale of recovered materials is not allowed on Government
property or at the Construction site, unless approved by the CO. Consider
the use of surplus industrial supply broker services, who match entities
with reusable or repurpose industrial materials with entities with need of
such materials.
1.11.2 Recycle
Recycle non-hazardous construction and demolition/debris materials that are
not suitable for reuse. Track rejection of contaminated recyclable
materials by the recycling facility. Rejected recyclables materials will
not be counted as a percentage of diversion calculation. Recycle all
fluorescent lamps, HID lamps, mercury (Hg) -containing thermostats and
ampoules, and PCBs-containing ballasts and electrical components as
directed by the CO. Do not crush lamps on site as this creates a hazardous
waste stream with additional handling requirements.
1.11.3 Compost
Consider composting off site if a reasonable amount of compostable
materials will be available and a utilization of compostable material can
be determined and appropriately planned for. Compostable materials include
plant materials, sawdust and certain food scraps. Composting as a strategy
must be explicitly addressed in the Construction Waste Management Plan
submitted for approval to ensure it is feasible.
1.11.4 Waste
Dispose by landfill or incineration only those waste materials with no
practical use, economic benefit, or recycling opportunity.

Not used.

SECTION 01 78 39.10 25
AS-BUILT DRAWINGS
PART 1 GENERAL
1.1 GENERAL INFORMATION
a. This Section covers as-built drawings completed, as a requirement of
the Contract. As-built drawings are redlined Contract drawings and
Contractor prepared drawings showing as-built conditions. As-built
drawings showing final as-built conditions of the work are defined, but
not limited to:
(1) Contract Drawings - Drawings created by the Government
specifically for this Contract and provided to the Contractor upon
Award. The Government will also provide CADD models used to
generate the Contract Drawings. As-built redline drawings are
copies of Contract drawings that are revised to show additions and
changes occurring during construction, eventually becoming final
record drawings.
(2) Contractor-Prepared Drawings - Drawings created by the
Contractor during execution of this Contract. Drawings must
include shop drawings, diagrammatic, and design information
provided by the Contractor and the Contractor's subcontractors,
vendors, or suppliers.
b. The Government will collate the Contractor's submittals into a final
as-built set.
1.2 REFERENCES
The publications listed below form a part of this Specification to the
extent referenced. The publications are referred to in the text by basic
designation only.
AMERICAN CONCRETE INSTITUTE (ACI)
ACI SP-66 (2004) ACI Detailing Manual
AMERICAN INSTITUTE OF STEEL CONSTRUCTION (AISC)
AISC 326 (2009) Detailing for Steel Construction

ERDC/ITL TR-19-7 (2019) A/E/C CAD Standard - Release 6.1

days, and resubmit to the Government for review and approval. Once
approved, submit a complete set of electronic PDF and CAD files.
1.8.1 CAD STANDARDS
a. The CAD standard mandated by US Army Corps of Engineers and this
Contract is ERDC/ITL TR-19-7. In addition to ERDC/ITL TR-19-7,
structural drawings must be in accordance with ACI SP-66 and AISC 326.
ERDC/ITL TR-19-7 is available, under the District CADD Standards, at
the following web link:
https://cadbimcenter.erdc.dren.mil/default.aspx?p=a&t=1&i=7. The web
link contains the guides, libraries, and templates that must be
utilized by the Contractor to produce CAD files that are compliant with
the CAD standards required in this Contract. The digital support files
in this web link are in DGN format (MicroStation).
b. Computer-Aided Design (CAD) work for this Contract must be
accomplished with personnel that are knowledgeable and experienced with
ERDC/ITL TR-19-7. Employ proficient personnel for the creation of CAD
files.
1.9 PAYMENT
a. Working as-built redline drawings will be jointly inspected for
accuracy and completeness by the CO and an authorized representative of
the Contractor prior to submission of the monthly pay estimate.
Failure to keep working as-built redline drawings maintained on a
current basis, in accordance with Paragraph WORKING AS-BUILT REDLINE
DRAWINGS, will be sufficient justification to withhold up to ten
percent of the monthly pay estimate.
b. Separate payment will not be made for compliance with this Section
for the preparation of the working as-built Contract and/or Shop
Drawing redline drawings. All costs associated with the working
as-built drawing requirements of this Section are considered incidental
to the work.

SECTION 02 41 00
DECOMMISSION OF OUTLET WORKS
PART 1 GENERAL
1.1 REFERENCES
The publications listed below form a part of this specification to the
extent referenced. The publications are referred to within the text by the
basic designation only.
AMERICAN SOCIETY OF SAFETY PROFESSIONALS (ASSP)
ASSP A10.6 (2006) Safety & Health Program
Requirements for Demolition Operations -
American National Standard for
Construction and Demolition Operations
U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS (USACE)
EM 385-1-1 (2024) Safety -- Safety and Occupational
Health (SOH) Requirements
1.2 PROJECT DESCRIPTION
1.2.1 Definitions
1.2.1.1 Decommission
To take something out of service, by any combination of closure operations,
demolition and deconstruction - see below.
1.2.1.2 Demolition
Demolition is the process of wrecking or taking out any load-supporting
structural member of a facility together with any related handling and
disposal operations.
1.2.1.3 Deconstruction
Deconstruction is the process of taking apart a facility with the primary
goal of preserving the value of all useful building materials.
1.2.1.4 Decommissioning Plan
Decommission Plan is the planned steps and processes for managing
demolition and other activities required for closure and identifying the
required sequencing activities and disposal mechanisms.
1.2.1.5 Leaks
Leaks are any flow from pipes, valves, equipment or penetration and
contacts with concrete exceeding a flow rate of one gallon in an 24 hour
time interval.
SECTION 02 41 00.00 25 Page 2
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
1.2.2 Demolition/Deconstruction Plan
The outlets works must be decommissioned to permanently close all conduits
through the dam to prevent any undue seepage of water or loss of control of
the reservoir. There is no value to the Government in any deconstructed
items. Prepare a Decommissioning Plan and submit proposed procedures for
approval 60 days before work is started. Include procedures for careful
removal and disposition of materials specified. Include a detailed
description of methods and equipment to be used for each operation and of
the sequence of operations. Coordinate with Section 01 57 19.00 25,
TEMPORARY ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROLS for addressing any liquid discharge or
abatement of lead and asbestos. Include statements affirming Contractor
inspection of the existing roof deck and its suitability to perform as a
safe working platform or if inspection reveals a safety hazard to workers,
state provisions for securing the safety of the workers throughout the
performance of the work. Include statements including any critical lifts
by cranes or special design of platforms or scaffolding inside valve pit
outside the monolith structure. Provide procedures for safe conduct of the
work in accordance with EM 385-1-1. Plan must be approved by Contracting
Officer (CO) prior to work beginning.
1.2.3 Outlet Works
The outlet works has 30 through-pipes (36 inch diameter)left over from
historical reservoir operations. The pipes extend from the upstream side
to the downstream side. The upstream end of the through-pipes are
underwater and saturated loose sediment. The slide gates on the top five
pipes are closed. The pipes extend through a valve pit about 6 feet wide
in the downstream direction. There is a knife valve on 25 of the 30
through-pipes on the upstream side of the valve pit. Some of the valves
are continually leaking and present a problem for placing and curing
concrete around them for decommissioning purposes. The water leaks must be
mitigated for under this Contract as described below. The remaining five
pipes on the upper level are only run with the sluice gates on the upstream
end. The through pipes are made of steel or concrete depending on location
however, portions within the valve pit are all steel. Steel segments exist
5 feet upstream of the knife valve and 15-feet downstream. The valve pit
is drained by six pipes (8 inch diameter) extending through 10 feet of
concrete on the downstream side. The valve pit is considered confined
space per EM 385-1-1. Government assumes the steel pipes with open sluice
gates and closed knife gates are partially filled with sediment because
some of the leaking valves have passed sediment into the valve pit. The
ventilation and lighting systems were operable during the last inspection
in March 2021, but those systems cannot be relied upon for this Contract.
The valves for the steel pipes operate on a pneumatic system. The
pneumatic air system does not work. There is no need to operate the valves
for decommissioning purposes. There is 6 to 18 inches of sediment in the
base of the valve pit. Detailed record drawings of the valve pit and all
features inside are provided in FIFO drawings.
1.2.4 General Requirements
Do not begin demolition or deconstruction until authorization is received
from the CO. Remove rubbish and debris from the project site; do not allow
accumulations inside or outside the outlet works except for approved
staging areas. In the interest of occupational safety and health, perform
the work in accordance with EM 385-1-1, Section 23, Demolition, and other
applicable Sections. Required activities for decommissioning include but
are not limited to the list below:
SECTION 02 41 00.00 25 Page 3
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
a. The outlet works contains 30 steel pipes that are 36-inches
diameter. 25 of those pipes have knife valve closures and 5 are open
pipes. The last Government inspection in 2021 identified 6 leaking
valves that will require hot tapping or an alternate plug method as
noted in Part 1.2.4(c). Without a recent inspection the current
conditions in the valve pit are unknown. The 25 pipes fitted with
valves forms the baseline valve hot tapping quantity for this
Contract. Document the pipes and valves with leaking conditions as
defined in Part 1.2.1.5 Leaks and submit a Valve Inspection Report to
the CO for approval.
b. Hot tap the leaking knife valves and pressurize with CONTROLLED LOW
STRENGTH MATERIAL (CLSM) per Section 03 52 01.00 25 or other type of
sealant to be reviewed and approved by the CO. The box should be
capable of draining the leaking water and have a port for pumping the
CLSM. The valve stem may be removed. The box or pump system must have
a pressure measuring device for quality control. The box must be
capable of containing a minimum pressures of 30 pounds per square inch.
The box must conform to at least two surfaces,
(1) the vertical face of the concrete upstream of the valve and
(2) the circumference of the steel pipe downstream of the valve.
The hot tap is intended to be permanent.
c. If the valve is leaking into the pipe, extend the hot tap in such a
way as to plug the pipe at the same time. Submit a shop drawing of the
planned fabrication along with the Decommissioning Plan. (Contractor
may submit to the CO for approval an alternate plan to plug the steel
pipe upstream of the knife valve if effective in stopping leaks.)
d. Clean and plug all steel through pipes (30) with CONTROLLED LOW
STRENGTH MATERIAL (CLSM) per Section 03 52 01.00 25 or other type of
sealant to be reviewed and approved by the CO. The inside of the pipes
must be cleaned of all sediment and debris. The plug extends from the
knife valve to the downstream end of the steel pipe. Place temporary
covers on the downstream end of the steel through pipes. Specify how
the temporary covers will be fixed in the decommissioning plan. No
permanent covers are allowed since the historic appearance must be
maintained.
e. There are six pipes (illustrated on the record drawings) that drain
the valve pit, all 8 inch diameter. Maintain drainage operation until
the valve pit is filled with concrete. Block the entrance of the
drainage pipes at the appropriate time to prevent from being filled
with concrete.
f. Remove all steel bolted to the interior of the valve pit including
grating and structural supports, ventilation pipes, all electrical
conductors and conduits, all pneumatic lines, and other miscellaneous
items identified during the initial survey. Also remove any
ventilation, electrical panels and hatch covers on the roof deck.
g. Clean mud from bottom of valve pit.
h. Place a layer of filter gravel on the bottom of the valve pit. The
gravel must be open graded crushed or uncrushed rock meeting SOT
specification 9-03.12(4) Gravel Backfill for Drains. Build a screen
SECTION 02 41 00.00 25 Page 4
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
for the lowest drain pipe at elevation 880 feet. The screen should
extend at least 2 inches above the crown of the pipe and extend down to
the pit floor and fastened to the vertical concrete face to prevent
movement during filter and CLSM placement. The screen must be HYDE and
have holes 3/8 inch diameter drilled at center spacing of 3/4 inch.
The screen should be capable of resisting forces due to the filter rock
layer and overlying liquid CLSM. The gravel must be a minimum of 8
inches deep across the pit floor and extend above the crown of the
lowest drainage pipe at elevation 880 feet. Cover the filter gravel
with a non-woven geotextiles and secure it so as to maintain horizontal
coverage while placing CLSM above it. Include details of the screen
and filter product source and method of securing textile placenta in
the decommissioning plan.
i. Fill the valve pit from bottom to Elevation 939 feet at the roof
deck with CONTROLLED LOW STRENGTH MATERIAL (CLSM) per Section
03 52 01.00 25, CONTROLLED LOW STRENGTH MATERIAL (CLSM). CLSM must be
flush with existing concrete surface.
1.3 AVAILABILITY OF WORK AREAS
All staging areas will be available for the purpose of this work throughout
the period of performance and these activities are not subject to in-water
work windows.
1.4 SUBMITTALS
Government approval is required for submittals with a "G" classification.
Submittals not having a "G" classification are for information only. When
used, a code following the "G" classification identifies the office that
will review the submittal for the Government. Submit the following in
accordance with Section 01 33 00, SUBMITTAL PROCEDURES:
SD-01 Preconstruction Submittals
Decommissioning Plan; G
Existing Conditions
Valve Inspection Report; G
SD-03 Product Data
Sealant; G
1.5 QUALITY ASSURANCE
Comply with Federal, State, and local hauling and disposal regulations. In
addition to the requirements of the "Contract Clauses," conform to the
safety requirements contained in ASSP A10.6. Use of explosives will not be
permitted.
1.6 PROTECTION
1.6.1 Protection of Personnel
Before, during and after the decommissioning work, continuously evaluate
the condition of the structure and take immediate action to protect all
personnel working in and around the project site. No area, section, or
SECTION 02 41 00.00 25 Page 5
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
component of floors, roofs, walls, columns, or other structural element
will be allowed to be left standing without sufficient bracing, shoring, or
lateral support to prevent collapse or failure while workmen remove debris
or perform other work in the immediate area.
1.7 EXISTING CONDITIONS
Before beginning any demolition or deconstruction work, survey the site and
examine the drawings and specifications to determine the extent of the
work. Record existing conditions in the presence of the CO showing the
condition of structures and other facilities adjacent to areas of
alteration or removal. Photographs sized 4 inch will be acceptable as a
record of existing conditions. Include in the record elevation views of
all features being demolished or filled with grout and extent of existing
cracks in structural walls and other damage and description of surface
conditions that exist prior to before starting work Submit survey results.
PART 2 PRODUCTS
2.1 GROUT
Grout for pipes must meet requirements of Section 03 52 01.00 25 CONTROLLED
LOW STRENGTH MATERIAL.
PART 3 EXECUTION
3.1 EXISTING FACILITIES TO BE REMOVED
3.1.1 Structures
a. Demolish structures in a systematic manner that conforms to safety
requirements of EM 385-1-1.
b. Locate demolition equipment throughout the structure and remove
materials so as to not impose excessive loads to supporting walls,
floors, or framing.
3.1.2 Utilities and Related Equipment
3.1.2.1 General Requirements
Do not interrupt existing utilities serving occupied or used facilities,
except when authorized in writing by the CO. Do not interrupt existing
utilities serving facilities occupied and used by the Government except
when approved in writing and then only after temporary utility services
have been approved and provided. Do not begin demolition or deconstruction
work until all utility disconnections have been made. Shut off and cap
utilities for future use, as indicated.
3.1.2.2 Disconnecting Existing Utilities
Remove existing utilities as indicated and uncovered by work and terminate
in a manner conforming to the nationally recognized code covering the
specific utility and approved by the CO. When utility lines are
encountered but are not indicated on the drawings, notify the CO prior to
further work in that area. Remove meters and related equipment and deliver
to a location in accordance with instructions of the CO.
SECTION 02 41 00.00 25 Page 6
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
3.1.3 Appurtenant Structures and Equipment
Protect existing chain link fencing, gates, and ladders
3.1.4 Roofing
Protect the existing roof and use existing access hatches. Remove access
hatches when done.
3.1.5 Structural Steel
Dismantle structural steel at field connections and in a manner that will
facilitate the decommissioning. Steel becomes the Contactor's property and
may be salvaged or recycled.
3.1.6 Mechanical Equipment and Fixtures
Disconnect mechanical hardware at the nearest connection to existing
services to remain, unless otherwise noted. Disconnect mechanical
equipment and fixtures at fittings.
3.1.6.1 Ducts
Classify removed duct work as scrap metal.
3.1.7 Electrical Equipment
Demolish all electrical equipment in the outlet works. Demolish all
conductors in the electrical conduits. Electrical conduits need to be
flushed out of any liquid, and sealed off permanently with urethane conduit
sealant to prevent any water seepage into the conduits.

a. Materials Analyses and Mixture Proportions Studies including

minimum of one mix design for Bedding Mortar and one mix design for
Dental Concrete.
1.6 SYSTEM DESCRIPTION
1.6.1 General Requirements
Perform all work in accordance with EM 385-1-1. Provide RCC composed of
cementitious materials, water, fine and coarse aggregates, and admixtures.
The cementitious material must be Portland cement, or a blended hydraulic
cement consisting of Portland cement in combination with either pozzolan or
limestone. An admixture, when approved or directed, will be a
water-reducing/retarding admixture. A blended hydraulic cement, when
approved or directed, must meet the same performance requirements for
Portland cement. The RCC mix designs must have minimum compressive
strength that meet or exceed the following requirements: 2500 psi at seven
days, 3500 psi at 28 days and 4000 psi at 90 days. All RCC must meet the
requirements specified herein.
1.6.2 Mixture Proportions and Studies
The Contractor must develop a primary RCC mixture and secondary RCC mixture
for the mass of the spillway. The primary mixture must contain
approximately 400 pounds Portland cement. The ratio of fine aggregate
content to the total aggregate content by weight must be between 36 and 40
percent, and there must be 30 ounces of the water-reducing/retarding
admixture per cubic yard. The mix must have a consistency which allows for
truck hauling, spreading with track, or wheeled equipment, and compaction
with a vibratory roller. Preparation of compressive strength specimens
must be in accordance with either ASTM C1176/1176M or ASTM C1435/C1435M.
The same method must be used for preparation of quality control (QC)
specimens as specified in PART 3, below.
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 10
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
1.6.3 Proportioning Responsibility
Adjustments will be made to the batch weights, including cement, pozzolan,
and water, to maintain the necessary consistency to prevent segregation
within the RCC and allow full compaction as determined. Frequent changes
to the batch weights must be considered usual and can be expected to occur
frequently during the course of each day's placement depending on such
variables as humidity, wind velocity, temperature, and cloud cover. Such
changes will be as directed. The Contractor must be responsible for
adjusting the added water to compensate for changes in aggregate moisture
content only.
1.6.4 Aggregates
Aggregates must meet the quality and grading requirements of ASTM C33/C33M
Size Number 2, Class Designation 4S or better except as modified herein.
Nominal maximum aggregate for all RCC must be 1 1/2 inch.
1.6.5 Consistency of RCC
The Contracting Officer (CO) will determine at the placement site on a
continuing basis the proper consistency necessary for adequate hauling,
spreading, and compacting and will direct all necessary changes to achieve
the proper RCC consistency. Changes will be directed based on visual
examination of the RCC during the spreading and compaction process and on
the Vebe time when it varies outside the range considered ideal for
compaction, as determined by the Government using the modified Vebe
apparatus, in accordance with COE CRD-C 53.
1.6.6 Construction Tolerances
The definitions of the terms used in the following Section must be as
defined in ACI 117. Make level and grade tolerance measurements as soon as
possible after finishing. When forms or shoring are used, the measurements
must be made prior to removal. Tolerances are not cumulative. The most
restrictive tolerance controls. Tolerances must not extend the structures
beyond legal boundaries. Except as specified otherwise, plus tolerance
increases the amount or dimension to which it applies or raises a level
alignment, and minus tolerance decreases the amount or dimension to which
it applied or lowers a level alignment. A tolerance without sign means
plus or minus. Where only one signed tolerance is specified, there is no
limit in the other direction.
1.6.7 RCC Surfaces
1.6.7.1 Lift Thickness
The thickness of compacted lifts of RCC must be within plus or minus 2
inches of that specified.
1.6.7.2 Lift Elevation
The elevation of the surfaces of RCC lifts upon which subsequent RCC is
placed must not vary more than 0.5 feet from the design elevation, except
that the elevation of the top three lifts of the dam must be within -0.0
feet or +0.2 feet of that shown.
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 11
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE

1.8 DELIVERY, STORAGE, AND HANDLING
1.8.1 Cementitious Materials
1.8.1.1 Transportation
When bulk cement or pozzolan is not unloaded from primary carriers directly
into weather-tight hoppers at the batching plant, transportation from the
railhead, mill, or intermediate storage to the batching plant must be
accomplished in adequately designed weather-tight trucks, conveyors, or
other means that will protect the material from exposure to moisture.
1.8.1.2 Storage
Furnish cementitious materials in bulk. Immediately upon receipt at the
site of the work, all cementitious materials must be stored in a dry,
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 12
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
weather-tight, and properly ventilated structure. All storage facilities
must permit easy access for inspection and identification. Sufficient
materials must be in storage for at least two operating days of continuous
placement. In order that cement may not become unduly aged after delivery,
use any cement that has been stored at the site for 60 days or more before
using cement of lesser age.
1.8.2 Aggregate Storage
Fine aggregate and each size of coarse aggregate must be stored in separate
size groups adjacent to the batch plant and in such a manner as to prevent
the intermingling of size groups or the inclusion of foreign materials in
the aggregate. Sufficient fine and coarse aggregate must be maintained at
the site for at least seven operating days of continuous placement.
1.8.3 Chemical Admixtures
Any admixture that has been in storage at the project site for longer than
recommended by the manufacturer or that has been subjected to freezing must
not be used in the work and must be removed from the site.
1.9 ENVIRONMENTAL REQUIREMENTS
If unusual adverse weather, such as heavy rain, severe cold, high winds,
heavy snow, etc., occurs or is forecast to occur during placement, the
placement operation must be suspended until conditions improve.
1.9.1 Placing During Rain
RCC must not be placed during rainfall of 0.1 inch/hr or more. During
periods of lesser rainfall, placement of RCC may continue if, in the
opinion of the CO, no damage to the RCC is occurring. Work must commence
only after excess free surface water and contaminated paste or RCC have
been removed and the surface has gained sufficient strength (no less than
four hours after the RCC placement was suspended) to prevent rutting,
pumping, intermixing of rainwater with the RCC, or other damage to the
RCC. When the RCC surface has been contaminated or damaged in any manner,
the RCC surface must be washed to break up and remove laitance or mud-like
coatings from the surface. Any undercut coarse aggregate must be removed.
All waste must be removed and disposed of in an approved manner.
1.9.2 Hot-Weather Placement
In hot-weather placement the temperature of the RCC must be controlled so
that it does not exceed 75.0 degrees F when placed. Placement must be
suspended as soon as the RCC temperature exceeds 75 degrees F. Measures
that can be taken to prevent temperatures exceeding 75 degrees F include,
but are not limited to, chilling mixing water, sprinkling aggregate
stockpiles, use of a canopy to shade the RCC placement areas, placing
during nighttime and early morning hours, or restricting placements to
cloudy days. Use of any of these systems must not be reason for extension
of completion dates specified in these specifications.
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 13
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
PART 2 PRODUCTS
2.1 MATERIALS
2.1.1 Cementitious Materials
2.1.1.1 Portland Cement
a. Unless otherwise specified, provide cement that conforms to
ASTM C150/C150M, Type II and meets low alkali content requirements.
The heat of hydration requirement at seven days must be no greater than
70 calories per gram. Portland cement must be furnished in bulk.
b. Portland-Limestone (i.e. PLC) Type IL cement conforming to
ASTM C595/C595M may also be used with a maximum of 15-percent
limestone. Limestone as defined in ASTM C51 must be natural occurring
and comply with the requirements of ASTM C595/C595M; including a
calcium carbonate content of at least 70 percent by mass in accordance
with Test Methods in ASTM C114. The low-alkali limitation must also be
met. Trial batches of the proposed RCC mix design with PLC Type IL will
be required to confirm material properties, low-alkali limitation, heat
of hydration, strength development rate, shrinkage, sulfate resistance,
workability, durability, admixture proportioning, etc. in accordance
with ASTM C595/C595M and AASHTO - M 240M/M 240.
c. Use one brand and type of cement for formed concrete having
exposed-to-view finished surfaces.
d. Submit information along with evidence demonstrating compliance with
referenced standards. Submittals must include types of cementitious
materials, manufacturing locations, shipping locations, and
certificates showing compliance.
e. Cementitious materials must be stored and kept dry and free from
contaminants.
2.1.1.2 Blended Cements
Blended cements must conform to ASTM C1157/C1157M, Type GU, MS, MH or LH
and meet low alkali content requirements. The heat of hydration
requirement at seven days must be no greater than 70 calories per gram.
Blended hydraulic cement must be furnished in bulk.
2.1.1.3 Pozzolan
Pozzolan must conform to ASTM C618, Class F, including requirements of
Table 2. Uniformity Requirements (for air content) must apply to all fly
ash. Loss on ignition (LOI) must be limited to six percent. Pozzolan must
be furnished in bulk.
2.1.1.4 Ground Granulated Blast-Furnace (GGBF) Slag
Ground Granulated Blast-Furnace Slag must conform to ASTM C989/C989M.
2.1.1.5 Temperature of Cementitious Materials
The temperature of the cementitious materials as delivered to the site must
not exceed 150 degrees F.
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 14
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
2.1.2 Admixtures
All chemical admixtures furnished as liquids must be in a solution of
suitable viscosity and dilution for field use as determined by the CO.
2.1.2.1 Water-Reducing Admixture (WRA)
WRA must meet the requirements of ASTM C494/C494M, Type D, except that the
six month and one year compressive strength tests are waived.
2.1.3 Water
Water for washing aggregates and for mixing and curing concrete must be
free from injurious amounts of oil, acid, salt, alkali, organic matter, or
other deleterious substances and must comply with COE CRD-C 400.
2.1.4 Aggregates
2.1.4.1 Composition
Fine and coarse aggregates proposed for use in concrete must be tested and
evaluated for alkali-aggregate reactivity in accordance with ASTM C1260.
The fine and coarse aggregates must be evaluated in the combination which
matches the Contractor's proposed mix design proportioning. Results of the
testing must have a measured expansion less than 0.10 percent at 16 days
after casting. Should the test data indicate an expansion of 0.10 percent
or greater, the aggregate(s) must be rejected or additional testing using
ASTM C1260 and ASTM C1567 must be performed. The additional testing using
ASTM C1260 and ASTM C1567 must be performed using the low alkali Portland
cement in combination with ground granulated blast furnace (GGBF) slag, or
Class F fly ash. GGBF slag must be used in the range of 40 to 50 percent
of the total cementitious material by mass. Class F fly ash must be used
in the range of 25 to 40 percent of the total cementitious material by mass.
2.1.4.2 Quality
Aggregates delivered to the mixer must meet the following requirements:
Aggregates must meet the quality and grading requirements of ASTM C33/C33M,
Size number 2, Class Designation 4S or better except as modified herein.

2.1.4.3 Grading
a. Fine Aggregate - The grading of the fine aggregate as delivered to
the mixer for the RCC must be such that the individual percent retained
on any sieve must not vary more than three percent from the percent
retained on that sieve in a fixed grading selected by the Contractor
after the first 30 days of concrete placement. The minimum percent
retained on each of the No. 8 through No. 200 sieve sizes must be five
percent. In additional to the grading limits, the fine aggregate, as
delivered to the mixer, must have a fineness modulus of not less than
2.10 nor more than 2.75. The grading of the fine aggregate must also
be controlled so that the fineness moduli for at least four of five
consecutive test samples of the fine aggregate as delivered to the
mixer must not vary more than 0.10 from the fineness modulus of the
fixed grading selected by the Contractor, and approved. The fineness
modulus must be determined in accordance with COE CRD-C 104. At the
option of the Contractor, fine aggregate may be separated into two or
more sizes or classifications, but the uniformity of the grading of the
separate sizes must be controlled so that they may be combined
throughout the job in fixed proportions established during the first 30
days of RCC placement. The fixed grading and the results of individual
tests during the first 30 days must fall within the following limits:

2.1.4.4 Particle Shape
The shape of the particles of the fine aggregate and of the coarse
aggregate must be generally spherical or cubical. The quantity of flat and
elongated particles at a length-to-width or width-to-thickness ratio
greater than three in the separated size groups of coarse aggregate, as
defined and determined by ASTM D4791, must not exceed 25 percent in any
size group.
2.1.4.5 Moisture Content
The fine aggregate must not be placed in bins at the batch plant until it
is in a stable state of moisture content. A stable moisture content must
be reached when the variation in the percent of total moisture tested in
accordance with ASTM C566 and when sampled at the same location will not be
more than 0.5 percent during one hour of the two hours prior to placing the
material in the batch plant bins and the variation in moisture content when
sampled at the same location must not be more than two percent during the
last eight hour period that the aggregate remains in the stockpile. The
coarse aggregate must be delivered to the mixers with the least amount of
free moisture and the least variation in free moisture practicable under
the job conditions. Under no conditions must the coarse aggregate be
delivered to the mixer "dripping wet."
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 17
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
2.2 PLANT AND EQUIPMENT
2.2.1 Concrete Plant
The concrete plant, conveying, placing, compaction, and cleanup systems
must have a minimum capacity of at least 200 cubic yards per hour. The
concrete plant must be a batch or a continuous mixing plant.
2.2.2 Location
The concrete plant must be located at the site of the work in the general
area indicated in the drawings.
2.2.3 Bins and Silos
Separate bins, compartments, or silos must be provided for each size or
classification of aggregate and for each of the cementitious materials.
The compartments must be of ample size and so constructed that the various
materials will be maintained separately under all working conditions.
2.2.4 Bulk Cement or Pozzolan
All compartments containing bulk cement or pozzolan must be separated from
each other by a free-draining air space. The cement and pozzolan bins must
be equipped with filters which allow air passage but preclude the venting
of cement or pozzolan into the atmosphere. All filling ports must be
clearly marked with a permanent sign stating the contents.
2.2.5 Batch Plant
Submit details and data on the concrete plant not later than 30 days after
Notice to Proceed for review by the CO. Final acceptance of any piece of
plant is subject to satisfactory performance during operation. The batch
plant must meet the following requirements.
2.2.5.1 Batchers
Aggregate must be weighed in separate weigh batchers with individual scales
or may be batched cumulatively. Bulk cement and other cementitious
materials must each be weighed on a separate scale in a separate weigh
batcher. Water must be measured by weight or by volume, but it must not be
weighed or measured cumulatively with another ingredient. Ice must be
measured separately by weight. Admixtures must be batched separately and
must be batched by weight or by volume in accordance with the manufacturers
recommendations.
2.2.5.2 Water Batcher
A suitable water-measuring and batching device must be provided that will
be capable of measuring and batching the mixing water within the specified
tolerances for each batch. The mechanism for delivering water to the
mixers must be free from leakage when the valves are closed. The filling
and discharge valves for the water batcher must be so interlocked that the
discharge valve cannot be opened before the filling valve is fully closed.
When a water meter is used, a suitable strainer must be provided ahead of
the metering device.
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 18
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
2.2.5.3 Admixture Dispensers
A separate batcher or dispenser must be provided for each admixture. Each
plant must be equipped with the necessary calibration devices that will
permit convenient checking of the accuracy of the dispensed volume of the
particular admixture. The batching or dispensing devices must be capable
of repetitively controlling the batching of the admixtures to the accuracy
specified. Piping for liquid admixtures must be free from leaks and
properly valved to prevent backflow or siphoning. The dispensing system
must include a device or devices that must detect and indicate the presence
or absence of the admixture or provide a convenient means of visually
observing the admixture in the process of being batched or discharged.
Each system must be capable of ready adjustment to permit varying the
quantity of admixture to be batched. Each dispenser must be interlocked
with the batching and discharge operations so that each admixture is added
separately to the batch in solution in a separate portion of the mixing
water in a manner to ensure uniform distribution of the admixtures
throughout the batch during the required mixing period. Storage and
handling of admixtures must be in accordance with the manufacturer's
recommendations.
2.2.5.4 Moisture Control
The plant must be capable of ready adjustment to compensate for the varying
moisture content of the aggregates and to change the masses of the
materials being batched. A moisture meter complying with the provisions of
COE CRD-C 143 must be provided for measurement of moisture in the fine
aggregate. The sensing element must be arranged so that the measurement is
made near the batcher charging gate of the sand bin or in the sand batcher.
2.2.5.5 Scales
Adequate facilities must be provided for the accurate measurement and
control of each of the materials entering each batch of concrete. The
weighing equipment and controls must conform to the applicable requirements
of NIST HB 44, except that the accuracy must be within 0.2 percent of the
scale capacity. Provide standard test weights and any other auxiliary
equipment required for checking the operating performance of each scale or
other measuring device. Tests must be made at the frequency required in
paragraph TESTS AND INSPECTIONS in PART 3 and in the presence of a
Government inspector. Each weighing unit must include a visible indicator
that must indicate the scale load at all stages of the weighing operation
and must show the scale in balance at zero load. The weighing equipment
must be arranged so that the concrete plant operator can conveniently
observe the indicators.
2.2.5.6 Operation and Accuracy
The weighing operation of each material must begin automatically when
actuated by one or more starter switches and must end when the designated
amount of each material has been reached. These requirements can be met by
providing a semiautomatic or automatic batching system as defined by the
NRMCA CPMB 100. There must be equipment to permit the selection of five
preset mixtures each by the movement of not more than two switches or other
control devices. The weigh batchers must be so constructed and arranged
that the sequence and timing of batcher discharge gates can be controlled
to produce a ribboning and mixing of the aggregates, water, admixtures, and
cementitious materials as the materials pass through the charging hopper
into the mixer. The plant must include provisions to facilitate the
