2.2.5.7 Interlocks
Batchers and mixers must be interlocked so that:
a. The charging device of each batcher cannot be actuated until all
scales have returned to zero balance within plus or minus 0.2 percent
of the scale capacity and each volumetric device has reset to start or
has signaled empty.
b. The charging device of each batcher cannot be actuated if the
discharge device is open.
c. The discharge device of each batcher cannot be actuated if the
charging device is open.
d. The discharge device of each batcher cannot be actuated until the
indicated material is within the allowable tolerances.
e. Admixtures are batched automatically and separately with the water.
f. The mixers cannot be discharged until the required mixing time has
elapsed.
2.2.5.8 Recorder
An accurate recorder or recorders must be provided and must conform to the
following detailed requirements:
a. The recorder must produce a graphical or digital record on a single
visible chart or tape of the weight or volume of each material in the
batchers at the conclusion of the batching cycle. The record must be
produced prior to delivery of the materials to the mixer. After the
batchers have been discharged, the recorder must show the return to
empty condition.
b. A graphical recording or digital printout unit must be completely
housed in a single cabinet that must be capable of being locked.
c. The chart or tape must be so marked that each batch may be
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 20
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
permanently identified and so that variations in batch weights of each
type of batch can be readily observed. The chart or tape must be
easily interpreted in increments not exceeding 0.5 percent of each
batch weight.
d. The chart or tape must show time of day at intervals of not more
than 15 minutes.
e. The recorder chart or tape must become the property of the
Government.
f. The recorder must be placed in a position convenient for observation
by the concrete plant operator and the Government inspector.
g. The recorded weights or volumes when compared to the weights or
volumes actually batched must be accurate within plus or minus two
percent.
2.2.5.9 Batch Counters
The plant must include devices for automatically counting the total number
of batches of all concrete batched and the number of batches of each preset
mixture.
2.2.5.10 Protection
The weighing, indicating, recording, and control equipment must be
protected against exposure to dust, moisture, and vibration so that there
is no interference with proper operation of the equipment.
2.2.6 Continuous Mixing Plant(s)
A continuous mixing plant(s) must be capable of producing RCC of the same
quality and uniformity as would be produced in a conventional batch plant
and must be capable of producing a uniform continuous product (at both
maximum and minimum production rates) that is mixed so that complete
intermingling of all ingredients occurs without balling, segregation, and
wet or dry portions.
2.2.6.1 Operation and Accuracy
An electronic control system must be provided. The control panel must
display for each ingredient the designed formula values and the
instantaneous percentage values and must record the instantaneous values at
a preset time interval and on demand with a multiple copy
printer/recorder. The recorder must note formula changes and must print
total quantities of each ingredient and total amounts produced on command.
There must be weighing devices (belt scale or other) for continuous
weighing of individual ingredients and total ingredients. The plant
control must not require manual devices to adjust the material flow. The
plant must be capable of total manual control operation for a single
product at a limited production for short-time durations in the event of
loss of electronic control. The electronic control system must incorporate
modular replaceable components to reduce down time in the event of control
system malfunction. An inventory must be maintained of such replaceable
components. The fine aggregate must have a device that monitors its
content immediately prior to dispensing into the mixing plant dispensing
system. The accuracy of the plant dispensing systems must be within the
following limits:
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 21
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
MATERIAL PERCENT OF REQUIRED MASS
Pozzolan 0 to +2 percent
Cement 0 to +2 percent
Water ± 1 percent
Aggregates ± 2 percent
Admixtures 0 to +6 percent
Note: The continuous feeders for each of the ingredients
must be calibrated in accordance with the manufacturer's
specifications. Devices and tools must be maintained at
the plant location to check the feeder's calibration at
the Contracting Officer's request. A technician must be
provided that is skilled in calibration of the feed
devices and the maintenance and repair of the plant
control system. The technician must be available within
30 minutes notice during all scheduled plant operations.
The technician could be one or more of the Contractor's
personnel.
2.2.6.2 Cement, Pozzolan, and Aggregate Feed
Cement, pozzolan, and aggregate must be uniformly, continuously, and
simultaneously fed (at the proper ratios and quantity for the mixture
required) into the mixer by belt, auger, vane feeder, or other acceptable
method. The feed bins or silos for each ingredient must be kept
sufficiently full and must be of sufficient size to ensure a uniform flow
at a constant rate for a specific mixture. The feed bins must have a
low-level indicator that both warns the operator and can shut the plant
down if insufficient material is available for a uniform and continuous
flow.
2.2.6.3 Water and Admixture Dispensers
The liquid-dispensing devices must be capable of metering and dispensing
within the specified requirements. The liquid valves must be free from
leakage in the closed position. The dispensers must have attachments or be
installed in such a manner that will permit convenient checking of their
accuracy. Plumbing must be leak-free and properly valved to prevent
backflow and siphoning. The dispenser must be interlocked with the
electronic plant control and must warn the operator and shut down the plant
if insufficient liquid is available. Separate nozzles for each liquid must
be properly located at the mixer to assure uniform distribution of each
liquid to the materials entering the mixer.
2.2.6.4 Continuous Mixer(s)
The continuous mixer(s) must have proper introduction of ingredients as
specified by the manufacturer and must not be charged in excess of the
manufacturer's recommended capacity. Mixer(s) must be capable of combining
the materials into a uniform homogeneous mixture and of discharging this
mixture without segregation. The mixer(s) must operate at the blade speed
designated by the manufacturer and must be capable of changing retention
time of the ingredients in the mixer. This should be accomplished by
manually resetting the mixer(s) blade angles. Mixing time (ingredient
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 22
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
retention time in the mixer) must be predicated upon the uniformity,
homogeneity, and consistency of the resultant mixture. Samples for
uniformity testing must be taken at two minute intervals and tested in
accordance with COE CRD-C 55 and paragraph MIXER UNIFORMITY REQUIREMENTS
below. The mixer(s) must be maintained in satisfactory operating condition
and mixer blades must be kept free of hardened concrete. Should mixer(s)
at any time produce unsatisfactory results, its use must be promptly
discontinued until it is repaired. Suitable facilities must be provided
for obtaining representative samples of concrete for testing. All
necessary platforms, shelters, tools, labor, and equipment must be provided
for obtaining samples.
2.2.6.5 Segregation
A means must be used to reduce and minimize segregation and waste which
would otherwise result from the continuous stream of concrete being fed
into the batch haul devices (concrete buckets, dump trucks, etc.). The
equipment must retain the concrete between tracks or other means of
transport to prevent the need for stopping the mixer. These devices could
include, but not be limited to, small-volume conveyor discharge hopper with
a large gate that is automatically opened on a timed interval, thereby
dumping a series of small batches into larger batch hoppers, trucks, or
truck beds.
2.2.6.6 Trial Operation
Not less than seven days prior to commencement of concrete placing, a test
of the plant must be made in the presence of a representative of the CO to
check operational adequacy. The number of cubic yards required to be
produced in trial runs must be as directed, but will not exceed 200 cubic
yards. All concrete produced in these tests must be wasted or used for
purposes other than inclusion in structures covered by this specification.
All deficiencies found in plant operation must be corrected to the
satisfaction of the CO prior to the start of concrete placing operations.
Mixer uniformity tests by the Government will be performed near the end of
this trial period. No separate payment will be made to the Contractor for
labor or materials required by provisions of this paragraph. Notify the CO
of the trial operation not less than seven days prior to the start of the
trial operation.
2.2.6.7 Protection
The weighing, indicating, recording, and control equipment must be
protected against exposure to dust, moisture, and vibration so that there
is no interference with proper operation of the equipment.
2.2.7 Laboratory Areas
A room must be provided adjacent to the plant to house the moisture and
grading testing equipment for aggregate and to provide working space for
the Government representative. Another room must be provided for testing
fresh concrete and for fabricating and initial curing (approximately 72
hours) of concrete test specimens in accordance with ASTM C31/C31M. The
size, arrangement, and location of these rooms will be subject to approval
by the CO. Provide electricity, air-conditioning, heat, and water as
required for use in these laboratory areas.
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 23
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
2.2.8 Mixers
Mixers must be stationary mixers or pugmill mixers. Truck mixers may be
used for bedding mortar. Mixers may be batch or continuous mixing. Each
mixer must combine the materials into a uniform mixture and discharge this
mixture without segregation. Mixers must not be charged in excess of the
capacity recommended by the manufacturer on the nameplate. Excessive
overmixing requiring additions of water will not be permitted. The mixers
must be maintained in satisfactory operating condition, and mixer drums
must be kept free of hardened concrete. Mixer blades or paddles must be
replaced when worn down more than 10 percent of their depth when compared
with the manufacturer's dimension for new blades. Should any mixer at any
time produce unsatisfactory results, its use must be promptly discontinued
until it is repaired or replaced.
2.2.9 Truck Mixers
Truck mixers may be used for mixing of bedding morter, only. Those mixers
must conform to the requirements of ASTM C94/C94M. Each truck must be
equipped with two counters from which it must be possible to determine the
number of revolutions at mixing speed and the number of revolutions at
agitating speed. The acceptability of truck mixers for uniform mixing must
be determined by uniformity tests in accordance with ASTM C94/C94M.
2.2.10 Pugmill Mixers
A batch or continuous mixing twin-shaft pugmill mixer must be capable of
producing RCC of the same quality and uniformity as would be produced in a
conventional plant that meets all the requirements of these specification.
All pugmill mixers must meet the requirements of paragraph CONTINUOUS
MIXING PLANT(S) above.
2.2.11 Mixer Uniformity Requirements
a. All mixers, except for truck mixers, will be tested by the
Government in accordance with this paragraph and in accordance with
COE CRD-C 55. When regular testing is performed, the conventional
concrete must meet the limits of any five of the six applicable
uniformity requirements, and the RCC must meet the limits of any three
of the four applicable uniformity requirements. When abbreviated
testing is performed, the concrete must meet only those requirements
listed for abbreviated testing. The initial mixer evaluation test must
be a regular test and must be performed prior to the start of concrete
placement. The concrete proportions used for the evaluation must
contain the largest size aggregate on the project and must be as
directed by the CO. Regular testing must consist of performing all
tests on three batches of concrete. The range for regular testing must
be the average of the ranges of the three batches. Abbreviated testing
must consist of performing the required tests on a single batch of
concrete. The range for abbreviated testing must be the range for one
batch. If more than one mixer is used and all are identical in terms
of make, type, capacity, condition, speed of rotation, etc., the
results of tests on one of the mixers must apply to the others, subject
to the approval of the CO. Mixer evaluations must be performed by the
Government. Provide labor and equipment as directed by the CO to
assist the Government in performing the tests.

2.2.12 Sampling Facilities
2.2.12.1 Sampling Concrete
Provide suitable facilities and labor for obtaining representative samples
of concrete in accordance with ASTM C172/C172M for Contractor quality
control and Government quality assurance testing.
2.2.12.2 Sampling Aggregates
Suitable facilities must be provided for readily obtaining representative
samples of aggregates for test purposes immediately prior to the material
entering the mixer.
2.2.13 Transporting and Conveying Equipment
The transporting and conveying equipment must conform to the following
requirements.
a. The concrete mixtures (RCC and bedding mortar) must be conveyed from
the plant mixer(s) to placement as rapidly and as continuously as
practical by methods which limit segregation, contamination, and
surface drying.
b. The RCC must be conveyed from the mixing plant to the structure by
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 25
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
means of main-line conveyor, end-dump truck, front-end loader, or a
combination thereof.
c. indicating and signaling devices must be provided for the control
and identification of types or classes of concrete as they are mixed
and discharged for transfer to the placement site.
d. Each type or class of concrete must be visually identified by
placing a colored tag or other marker as it leaves the mixing plant so
that the concrete may be positively identified and placed in the
structure in the desired position.
2.2.13.1 Trucks
Truck mixers or agitators used for transporting bedding morter must conform
to the applicable requirements of ASTM C94/C94M. Bodies of nonagitating
trucks must be smooth, water-tight, metal containers specifically designed
to transport concrete, shaped with rounded corners to minimize segregation.
2.2.13.2 Belt Conveyors
Belt conveyors must be designed and operated to assure a uniform flow of
concrete from mixer or delivery truck to final place of deposit without
segregation of ingredients or loss of mortar and must be provided with
positive means for preventing segregation of the concrete or loss of mortar
at transfer points and the point of placing. The NMSA required in mixture
proportions furnished by the Government will not be changed to accommodate
the belt width.
2.2.14 Spreading and Remixing Equipment
The spreading and remixing equipment must conform to the following
requirements:
a. The primary spreading procedure must be accomplished by dozer.
Graders or other equipment not specified may be used to facilitate the
RCC spreading process only when approved.
b. For open, unrestricted areas, the dozer must be a minimum size and
weight equivalent to a Caterpillar D-6. For restricted placement
areas, such as placement of RCC near the dam crest or next to
abutments, the dozer must have as a minimum a size and weight
equivalent to a Caterpillar D-4.
c. A minimum of one operating dozer for each 200 cubic yards of RCC
placed each hour. The dozers must be equipped with well maintained
grousers. A front-end loader with operator must be available to assist
with deposition and spreading of RCC as needed in confined areas.
d. The equipment must be maintained in good operating condition. The
equipment must not leak or drip oil, grease, or other visible
contaminants onto the RCC surface.
e. All equipment used for spreading and remixing that leaves the
surface of the structure for maintenance or repairs or, for any other
reason, must be cleaned of all contaminants by an approved method
before returning to the structure surface. Under no conditions must a
dozer or other tracked vehicle be operated on other than fresh
uncompacted RCC except to facilitate startup operations for each lift
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 26
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
and by approved procedures.
2.2.15 Compaction Equipment
Submit a listing of the equipment proposed for transporting, handling,
depositing, spreading, and compacting the concrete for review by the CO not
later than 30 days after Notice to Proceed. Include site drawings or
sketches with locations of equipment and placement site. The compaction
equipment must conform to the following requirements.
2.2.15.1 Primary Rollers
Self-propelled vibratory rollers must be used for primary rolling and must
be double-drum. They must transmit a dynamic impact to the surface through
a smooth steel drum by means of revolving weights, eccentric shafts, or
other equivalent methods. The compactor must have a minimum gross mass of
20,000 pounds and must produce a minimum dynamic force of 350 pounds/linear
inch of drum width. The operating frequency must be variable in the
approximate range of 1,700 to 3,000 cycles per minute. The amplitude must
be adjustable between 0.015 and 0.04 inches. The roller must be capable of
full compaction in both forward and reverse directions. The roller must be
operated at speeds not exceeding 2.2 ft/s. Within the range of the
operating capability of the equipment, the CO may direct or approve
variations to the frequency, amplitude, and speed of operation which result
in the specified density at the fastest production rate.
2.2.15.2 Small Vibratory Rollers
Small vibratory rollers must be used to compact the RCC where the larger
vibratory rollers specified above cannot maneuver. The rollers must
compact the RCC to the required density and must be so demonstrated during
construction of the test section. Small vibratory rollers cannot compact
the RCC to the same density and thickness as the primary rollers;
therefore, when small rollers are used, total lift thickness of the RCC
layer or lift must be reduced to not over 6 inches uncompacted thickness to
permit adequate compaction. Rollers must have independent speed and
vibration controls and must be capable of a wide range of speed adjustments.
2.2.15.3 Tampers (Rammers)
The tampers must compact the RCC to the required density and must be so
demonstrated during construction of the test section. Tampers cannot
compact the RCC to the same density and thickness as the primary rollers;
therefore, when tampers are used, thickness of each RCC layer that is to be
compacted must be reduced to not more than 6 inches uncompacted thickness
to assure adequate compaction.
2.2.16 Truck-Mounted Vacuum Pickup System
A truck-mounted vacuum pickup system must be provided for various cleanup
operations from the beginning of foundation cleanup to final placement of
job RCC. The unit(s) must be capable of pumping 4,500 cubic feet of air
per minute through an 8 inch diameter opening and capable of pumping water
at a minimum rate of 2,000 gpm. The equipment must be maintained in good
operating condition. The equipment must not leak cleanup water and other
debris during equipment operation or transit. The equipment must not leak
or drip oil, grease, or other visible contamination onto the RCC.
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 27
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
2.2.17 Other Motorized Equipment
All other equipment (backhoe with vibratory plate, backhoe with immersion
vibrators, backhoe with mandrel for inserting contraction joint plates,
wash trucks, etc.) necessary for the successful completion of RCC
production, but not previously discussed within these specifications (or
determined to be necessary during the course of the work), must be approved
prior to actual use. Such equipment must not result in any damage to the
RCC, must be maintained in good operating condition, and must be operated
by skilled Contractor-provided personnel.
2.2.18 Nuclear Density Gauge
Tests to determine the density of both the uncompacted and compacted RCC
must be made by the Contractor using a two-probe nuclear density gauge
supplied by the Contractor. The nuclear density gauge must meet the
applicable requirements of ASTM C1040/C1040M. The gauge must be capable of
taking readings along a horizontal path between the probes at 2 inch
increments from 2 inches from the surface to 24 inches below the surface.
The gauge and operator must be made available to the Government until
completion of all RCC production at no additional cost. Obtain all permits
and certifications for the equipment and the operators.
2.2.19 Calibration
Nuclear gauges must have been factory calibrated within six months of RCC
placement. Construct, at no additional costs to the Government, three
conventional concrete test blocks using RCC coarse aggregates and RCC fine
aggregate, and with dimensions 12 inches larger than the gauge dimensions.
The concrete must be formulated to have densities of approximately 130,
145, and 160 lb/cu ft using the RCC materials and so far as possible,
similar relative proportions. Completed blocks must be weighed and
measured to determine unit weight. Gauge calibration constants must be
adjusted for performance on these blocks at least seven days prior to the
evaluation of test strips. Remedy any inconsistencies in gauge performance
prior to the start of RCC placement. After the start of RCC placement,
gauges must be field recalibrated against cast blocks every 24 hours.
PART 3 EXECUTION
3.1 PREPARATION FOR PLACING
3.1.1 Placing Schedule
At least seven days before starting RCC production, a detailed schedule
must be submitted indicating intended daily and weekly production rates
that, when followed, will meet the beginning and ending specified RCC
production dates. This RCC lift plan is to include the plan and sequence of
work, including graphical depictions of lifts based off of the foundation
survey. After initiation of RCC production, the Contractor's schedule must
be updated and adjusted on a weekly basis for the duration of the RCC
placement. If it becomes apparent for any reason that the Contractor is
not pursuing a schedule that will meet the specified RCC production dates,
actions necessary to increase the production rate must be taken so that
production is once again on schedule, within five calendar days after
written notice. Also, if not back on schedule by the end of the seven day
period, the Government reserves the right at this time to direct the
Contractor, at no additional cost to the Government, to increase the amount
and size of crews and equipment.
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 28
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
3.1.2 RCC Orientation Session
Prior to or in conjunction with the construction of the RCC test section,
supervisors and all other Contractor personnel which are expected to
participate in the production of RCC for this job (including laborers,
equipment operators, foremen, and QC and inspection staff) must participate
in a two-hour orientation session organized by the Contractor and led by
their RCC specialist. Provide a facility suitable for slide and videotape
presentation. The intent is to orient all individuals on the goals of the
RCC placement process, provide clarification of specification requirements
if requested, and be provided orientation as to what constitutes good
construction practices. Additional orientation sessions will also be made
available to, and must be attended by, all new Contractor personnel who are
subsequently hired and that will be involved with the production of the RCC.
3.1.3 Aggregate Production Schedule
Aggregate production and initial stockpiling must begin and must be
producing acceptable material by not later than seven days in advance of
the time when placement of the RCC test section is expected to begin.
Submit descriptions and details for all methods and operations proposed for
aggregate and concrete operations including daily and weekly production
rates, not later than 15 days after Notice to Proceed for review and
approval for conformance with specifications.
3.1.4 RCC Test Section
Prior to placement of any RCC, construct a test section. The purpose of
the test section is to demonstrate the suitability of the Contractor's
equipment, methods, and personnel. The test section must be at least three
lifts in height and be at least 100 feet long and 20 feet wide at the top.
The site of the test section must be approved. Trial batches can be done
in conjunction with the test section. After evaluation and assessment of
the test section by the CO, dispose of the test section in an approved
manner. Under no circumstances must the test section be incorporated into
or become a part of the permanent RCC structure. The test section must
demonstrate sustained plant production rates, and batching, mixing,
transporting, spreading, and compaction procedures. It must also
demonstrate the vertical face construction method along one side, the
sloped face construction method along another side, procedures for
foundation and concrete surface preparation and cleanup, procedures for
placement of concrete, bedding mortar, and other conventional concrete.
Do not begin RCC operations for the main structure until testing and
evaluations by the Government have been completed, and it has been
demonstrated to the satisfaction of the CO that all specification
requirements were met. Following completion of test section construction,
10 days must be allowed for testing and evaluations. If the Contractor
does not meet requirements as specified, an additional test section or
sections must be constructed at no additional cost to the Government. The
date of the test section construction must be provided at least seven days
in advance.
3.1.5 Surface Preparation
3.1.5.1 Cleaning
All lift surfaces including any RCC, dental concrete, concrete, bedding
mortar, or other conventional concrete placed adjacent to and at the same
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 29
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
time as the RCC must be cleaned prior to placing any additional concrete
thereon. After cleaning, concrete and bedding mortar are to be used
specifically for achieving bond between different types of concrete and
foundation and eliminating and preventing segregation or voids along
margins or RCC placements. No surfaces to receive concrete or bedding
mortar must be covered with RCC until the prepared surfaces have been
accepted in writing and that acceptance has been recorded on an approved
checkout form. All surfaces upon which RCC or any bedding mortar placed
must be moist (but contain no visible free water). Prior to placing any
concrete adjacent to and at the same time as the RCC, all surfaces must be
clean and free of loose, unkeyed, or deteriorated rock; all mud and silt
accumulations; vegetation; laitance; puddles or ponds of free surface
water; coatings; and any other detrimental materials. High-pressure water
jetting, or wet sandblasting, followed by mild high-volume, low-pressure
washing, must be used on all hardened concrete surfaces (cold joints) as
necessary for the removal of laitance, coatings, stains, or other
difficult-to-remove contaminants. High-volume low-pressure water washing
or water jetting may be used for removal of loose materials. Adequate
equipment with operators must be on hand at the site to clean all surfaces
in conformance with these specifications without disrupting in any way the
RCC production as scheduled.
3.1.5.2 High-Volume Low-Pressure Washing
Washing of loose materials can be accomplished with high-volume
low-pressure water washing or air water jetting using equipment of similar
design to that used in large-scale foundation cleanups. The air-water jets
must have 1 1/2 inch nozzles, a water supply of at least 30 gpm, and
compressed air at the jet of 80 to 120 psi. The low-pressure water jets
must have one inch nozzles available and a capacity of at least 200 gpm for
truck-mounted devices.
3.1.5.3 High-Pressure Water Jet
A stream of water under a pressure of not less than 1,500 psi for RCC and
4,000 psi for conventional concrete must be used for cleaning all cold
joint surfaces, or surfaces with laitance, mortar coatings, stains, or
other difficult-to-remove contaminants. There must be no undercutting of
coarse-size aggregates. Aggregate particles that are undercut must be
removed. For cleaning large open areas larger than 5,000 square feet, the
high-pressure water jet system must be truck-mounted. For cleaning small
or confined areas, the high-pressure water jet system must be portable.
3.1.5.4 Waste Disposal
Any waste water employed in cutting, washing, and rinsing of concrete
surfaces, and any other surface water must not stain, or affect exposed
surfaces of the structure(s) or damage the environment of the project
area. The method of disposal must be subject to approval.
3.2 PLACING
3.2.1 Procedures
It is the intent of this Contract to raise the structure at essentially the
same level across the entire horizontal surface area. As the advancing
edge of the lift progresses, the exposed leading edges must be kept "live"
by progressively placing out from the advancing edge in a sloping and
uniform fan-like manner. RCC must be deposited (from the conveyor,
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 30
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
end-dump truck, or front-end loader) on the uncompacted RCC of the
advancing edge in a forward direction from the dump pile. RCC must not be
placed in consecutive or consistent lanes. The dump location must be
varied to avoid "lane" construction. The interval between batch plant
mixing and final RCC compaction must be no greater than 45 minutes. Final
compaction is defined as: Any RCC lift composed of layers that have been
worked twice by dozer grousers, receives four passes with the vibratory
roller, and meets the density requirements.
3.2.2 Bedding Mortar
The bedding mortar must be applied to the existing surface following any
required cleanup. The bedding mortar must be applied not more than 15
minutes ahead of RCC placement, unless otherwise approved. The bedding
mortar must be used between hardened conventional concrete and RCC, between
different RCC placements where cold joints occur, and other locations as
directed or as shown in the drawings. The bedding mortar must have an
average thickness after application of between 1/4 and 1/2 inch and must
cover 100 percent of the lift area.
3.2.3 Lift Thickness
The total lift thickness after final compaction by the vibratory roller
must be 12 inches.
3.2.4 Depositing, Spreading, and Remixing
After the RCC has been deposited, the RCC must be spread by dozers into
gently sloping layers, approximately 6 inches thick, that will, after final
compaction of the several layers by the vibratory roller, result in the
specified lift thickness. During the spreading process, the dozer
operators must continuously work the RCC surfaces with the dozer blade and
grousers in a manner to remix any RCC that may contain pockets of
segregated material and to compact the material. All surfaces of each
layer must receive at least two passes with the grousers. The dozers must
be operating continuously during the spreading process, even if this action
results in more than two passes. A front-end loader with operator must be
available to assist with depositing and spreading RCC as needed in confined
areas, at the abutments, and at other locations approved or directed. In
no case must the RCC, or bedding mortar be allowed to dry. Under no
conditions must a dozer or other tracked vehicle be operated on other than
fresh uncompacted RCC except at the start of each lift placement to
facilitate startup operations, and then only by an approved procedure. No
RCC or other concrete must be placed on a previous lift which has not met
specification. Unacceptable material must be removed.
3.2.5 Compaction/Consolidation
After spreading and working with the dozers, the top surface of each lift
must be compacted with a minimum of four, plus as many additional passes
with a self-propelled double-drum vibratory roller operating in the
vibratory mode as are required to obtain a minimum of 98 percent of the
theoretical density. A round trip over the same material must count as two
passes (i.e., from point A to point B and return to point A by the same
route is two passes). Rollers must not be operated in the vibratory mode
unless they are moving
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 31
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
3.2.5.1 Theoretical Density (TD) Determination
The TD is defined as the theoretical density (unit weight) of the concrete,
pounds per cubic foot, computed to including air content. The TD value to
be used during construction will be determined using job mixture
proportions and Contractor supplied materials; and, using compaction
techniques suitable for RCC, and following the appropriate testing
procedures used to determined theoretical unit weight of concrete as
described as in ASTM C138/C138M.
3.2.5.2 Required Compaction Density
All RCC must be compacted to a minimum of 98 percent of the TD value. The
anticipated TD, estimated from laboratory test data is approximately 160
pounds per cubic foot.
3.2.5.3 Density Determination of Compacted RCC
Density must be measured using a nuclear density meter in accordance with
ASTM C1040/C1040M. RCC density value determinations must be made
throughout the course of RCC placement to assure that the RCC is compacted
to a minimum 98 percent of the TD and detect segregation or voids
throughout the RCC. Submit findings of all tests as part of the Concrete
Strength Report.
3.2.5.4 Additional Compaction
If more than four passes are required to achieve the required density, the
additional passes must be made at no additional cost to the Government.
3.2.6 Lift Joints
The entire RCC mass must be placed with sufficient continuity so that it
hardens and acts as one monolithic block without discontinuous joints or
potential planes of separation. All lift joints must be kept clean,
uncontaminated, free from ponded water, and continuously moist until
placement of the succeeding RCC or other concrete.
3.2.6.1 Regular Lift-Joint Treatment
a. Lift joints that have not hardened or dried and are less than 72
hours old must be given the regular lift-joint treatment. Submit the
method and equipment proposed for joint cleanup and waste disposal for
review by the CO not later than 30 days after Notice to Proceed for
conformance with specifications. Regular lift-joint treatment and
maintenance must include:
(1) Maintaining 100 percent of each compacted lift-joint surface
continuously moist,
(2) If necessary, removing all loose contaminants or deteriorated
RCC by low-pressure washing or vacuuming, and
(3) Application of a 1/4 to 1/2 inch thick bedding mortar over the
entire placement surface area immediately before placement of the
next lift.
b. For regular lift-joint treatment, no washing or vacuuming will be
necessary provided damage or contamination of the lift surface is
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 32
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
prevented.
3.2.6.2 Cold Joints
a. A cold joint is any vertical or horizontal RCC surface:
(1) That does not receive the next RCC lift within 72 hours,
(2) In which the RCC has been allowed to dry, or
(3) That has been contaminated to the extent that contaminants
cannot be removed using low-pressure water.
b. Cold joints must be prepared for the next lift by the methods and
procedures in paragraph SURFACE PREPARATION above, prior to resumption
of RCC placement. Following this initial preparation, the cold-joint
surface must be kept continuously moist until application of the
bedding mortar. Whenever a cold joint at any edge or end of any lift
occurs, it must be located at least 30 feet from the location of other
cold joints that may have previously occurred in the same direction
along previous lifts.
3.2.6.3 Unplanned Cold Joints
Cold joints between adjacent placements of RCC must not be scheduled.
However, if an unplanned joint occurs, it must be treated as follows:
a. Unplanned Cold-Joints will be treated as described above.
Additionally they must be treated as described hereafter.
b. Shoulders must be broken down and feathered out such that the
vertical rise does not exceed the layer height for each horizontal
distance equal to the roller width, and
c. The hardened RCC surface must be prepared for receiving the next
layer of RCC by cleaning with air supplemented with water to remove all
loose material. RCC surfaces which are to receive additional concrete
are considered to be cold joints if the hardened RCC surface is over 72
hours old, or has been contaminated to the extent that contaminants
cannot be removed using low pressure water.
3.2.6.4 Vertical Joints
Joints for sloping, near-vertical or vertical RCC surfaces are considered
to be vertical joints. A vertical joint most often will occur when an RCC
placement is terminated before the entire RCC placement for that lift has
been completed. When it does become apparent that placement of RCC will be
terminated prior to completion of a lift, the RCC spreading procedure at
the leading zone of the placement must be adjusted to provide a gradual
tapered slope to complete that lift. The taper must be no steeper than 25
horizontal on one vertical. Where the tapered slope meets the underlying
hardened lift surface, care must be taken to prevent or remove any
segregated or uncompacted material. The tapered surface must be compacted
in accordance with paragraph COMPACTION/CONSOLIDATION above. Prior to
resumption of RCC placements, the tapered surface must be prepared in
accordance with paragraph SURFACE PREPARATION above.
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 33
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
3.2.7 Downstream Face
The downstream sloped face of the dam and the exposed slopes of the
stilling basin training walls must be constructed using sacrificial RCC on
1.0 vertical to 0.9 horizontal slope. The slope must be constructed to the
tolerances specified. Each RCC lift must be overbuilt at least 12 inches,
and it must subsequently be trimmed to the surface smoothness tolerance.
Trimming must be performed before the RCC is more than 48 hours old. The
process must be demonstrated during the test section. Trimming must be
done in such a manner to prevent damage to the surface and interior RCC.
3.3 CURING AND PROTECTION
Submit the curing media and methods to be used for review to the CO 14 days
before concrete placement begins for conformance with specifications.
3.3.1 Curing
The surface of every RCC lift must be kept continuously moist, commencing
immediately after compaction, by use of water trucks equipped with fog
sprayers for 14 days or until the surface is covered with the next lift.
Uncompacted sacrificial RCC, need not be cured. Concrete that is moist
cured must be maintained continuously, not periodically, wet for the
duration of the entire curing period. Water for curing must comply with
the requirements of paragraph entitled Water. If the water or mats cause
staining or discoloration of permanently exposed concrete surfaces, the
surfaces must be cleaned by a method approved by the CO. When wood or
metal forms are left in place during curing, the forms must be kept
continuously wet, except for sealed insulation curing in cold weather. RCC
may be cured with saturated cotton or burlap mats in lieu of the approved
fog spraying equipment. The RCC must meet a 7 day minimum compressive
strength of 2,500 psi prior to releasing water over the newly placed
concrete.
3.3.2 Hot-Weather Protection
When ambient air temperatures exceeds 90 degrees F and as soon as the
conventional concrete and RCC is sufficiently hard to withstand washing of
surface mortar, water by fog spraying must be applied in a controlled
manner to provide evaporative cooling. Water must be applied at such a
rate that it quickly evaporates and such that the surface remains
continuously moist without ponding. In addition, when surface materials
begin to dry and while the RCC placement, spreading, and compaction process
is still underway and until the concrete has sufficiently hardened to
permit the above water spray, hand-held fog spraying must be applied to the
concrete surfaces as directed to prevent drying out of concrete materials
and replace moisture lost to evaporation. These hot-weather protection
procedures will require additional labor(s) to assure complete coverage of
the entire surface areas to prevent unacceptable damage to the RCC and
conventional concrete. Submit a description of the materials and methods
proposed for protection of the concrete, when concrete is to be placed
under hot-weather conditions, to the CO for review 30 days in advance of
anticipated need date.
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 34
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE

3.4.1 Finishing
The ambient temperature of spaces adjacent to surfaces being finished must
be not less than 50 degrees F. In hot weather when the rate of evaporation
of surface moisture, as determined by use of Figure 2.1.5 of ACI 305R, may
reasonably be expected to exceed 0.2 lb/sq ft per hour, provisions for
windbreaks, shading, fog spraying, or wet covering with a light-colored
material must be made in advance of placement, and such protective measures
must be taken as quickly as finishing operations will allow. All unformed
surfaces that are not to be covered by additional concrete or backfill must
have a float finish, unless a trowel finish is specified, and must be true
to the elevation shown. Surfaces to receive additional concrete or
backfill must be brought to the elevation shown in the drawings and left
true and regular. Exterior surfaces must be sloped for drainage unless
otherwise shown or as directed. Joints must be carefully made with a
jointing or edging tool. The finished surfaces must be protected from
stains or abrasions.
3.5 TESTS AND INSPECTIONS
3.5.1 General
Perform the inspection and tests as described below, and based upon the
results of these inspections and tests, he must take the action required
and submit reports as required. When, in the opinion of the CO, the
concreting operation is out of control, concrete placement must cease. The
laboratory performing the tests must be on-site and must conform with
ASTM C1077. The individuals who sample and test concrete or the
constituents of concrete as required in this specification must have
demonstrated a knowledge and ability to perform the necessary test
procedures equivalent to the ACI minimum guidelines for certification of
Concrete Field Testing Technicians, Grade I. The individual who performs
the inspection must have demonstrated a knowledge and ability equivalent to
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 35
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
the ACI minimum guidelines for certification of Concrete Construction
Inspector (CCI), Level II. The Government will inspect the laboratory,
equipment, and test procedures prior to start of concreting operations and
at least once per year thereafter for conformance with ASTM C1077.
3.5.2 Testing and Inspection Requirements
3.5.2.1 Fine Aggregate
3.5.2.1.1 Grading
At least once during each shift when the concrete plant is operating, there
must be one sieve analysis and fineness modulus determination in accordance
with ASTM C136/C136M, ASTM C117, and COE CRD-C 104 for the fine aggregate
or for each fine aggregate if it is batched in more than one size or
classification. The location at which samples are taken may be selected by
the Contractor as the most advantageous for control. However, the
Contractor is responsible for delivering fine aggregate to the mixer within
specification limits. The results must be recorded on a sheet on which are
also shown the specification limits applicable to the project.
3.5.2.1.2 Fineness-Modulus Control Chart
Results for fineness modulus must be grouped in sets of three consecutive
tests, and the average and range of each group must be plotted on a control
chart. The upper and lower control limits for average must be drawn 0.10
units above and below the target fineness modulus, and the upper control
limit for range must be 0.20.
3.5.2.1.3 Corrective Action for Fine Aggregate Grading
When the amount passing on any sieve is outside the specification limits,
the fine aggregate must be immediately resampled and retested. If there is
another failure on any sieve, the fact must immediately be reported to the
CO. Whenever a point on the fineness modulus control chart, either for
average or range, is beyond one of the control limits, the frequency of
testing must be doubled. If two consecutive points are beyond the control
limits, the process must be considered out of control and concreting must
be stopped. The CO must be notified, and immediate steps must be taken to
rectify the situation. After two consecutive points have fallen within the
control limits, testing at the normal frequency may be resumed.
3.5.2.1.4 Moisture Content Testing
When in the opinion of the CO the electric moisture meter is not operating
satisfactorily, there must be at least four tests for moisture content in
accordance with ASTM C566 during each eight hour period of mixing plant
operation. The times for the tests must be selected randomly within the
eight hour period. An additional test must be made whenever the slump is
out of control or excessive variation in workability is reported by the
placing foreman. When an electric moisture meter is operating
satisfactorily, at least two direct measurements of moisture content must
be made per week to check the calibration of the meter. The results of
tests for moisture content must be used to adjust the added water in the
control of the batch plant.
3.5.2.1.5 Moisture Content Corrective Action
Whenever the moisture content of the fine aggregate changes by 0.5 percent
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 36
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
or more from the previous sample, the scale settings for the fine aggregate
batcher and water batcher must be adjusted (directly or by means of a
moisture compensation device).
3.5.2.2 Coarse Aggregate
3.5.2.2.1 Grading
At least once during each shift in which the concrete plant is operating,
there must be a sieve analysis in accordance with ASTM C136/C136M for each
size of coarse aggregate. The location at which samples are taken may be
selected by the Contractor as the most advantageous for production
control. A test record of samples of aggregate taken at the same locations
must show the results of the current test as well as the average results of
the five most recent tests including the current test. The Contractor may
adopt limits for control coarser than the specification limits for samples
taken other than as delivered to the mixer to allow for degradation during
handling. When facilities are available to test samples five times as
large as those required in ASTM C136/C136M, no averaging must be done.
3.5.2.2.2 Corrective Action for Grading
When the amount passing any sieve is outside the specification limits, the
coarse aggregate must be immediately resampled and retested. If the second
sample fails on any sieve, that fact must be reported to the CO. Where two
consecutive averages of five tests (or two consecutive tests where large
samples are used) are outside specification limits, the operation must be
considered out of control, and that fact must be reported to the CO,
concreting must be stopped, and immediate steps must be taken to correct
the grading.
3.5.2.2.3 Coarse Aggregate Moisture Content
A test for moisture content of each size group of coarse aggregate must be
made at least once a shift. When two consecutive readings for smallest
size coarse aggregate differ by more than one percent, frequency of testing
must be increased to that specified previously for fine aggregate.
3.5.2.2.4 Coarse Aggregate Moisture Corrective Action
Whenever the moisture content of any size of coarse aggregate changes by
0.5 percent or more from the previous sample, the scale setting for the
coarse aggregate batcher and the water batcher must be adjusted to
compensate for this.
3.5.2.2.5 Material Finer than the No. 200 Sieve
When in the opinion of the CO, a problem exists in connection with the
cleanliness of the coarse aggregate, tests must be made in accordance with
ASTM C117. Testing frequency must be as directed.
3.5.2.2.6 Corrective Action for material finer than the No. 200 Sieve
When material finer than the No. 200 sieve exceeds one percent of the
weight of the coarse aggregate finer than 1 1/2 inch or 0.5 percent of the
weight of the aggregate coarser than 1 1/2 inch, the CO must be notified,
and steps, such as washing or other corrective action, must be initiated
immediately.
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 37
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
3.5.2.3 Quality of Aggregates
3.5.2.3.1 Frequency of Quality Tests
Prior to submitting samples for mixture proportioning studies, perform the
tests for aggregate quality in the following list. In addition, after the
start of concrete placement, perform tests for aggregate quality during
concrete or aggregate production, in accordance with the following
frequency schedule. Samples tested after the start of concrete placement
must be taken immediately prior to entering the concrete mixer.

3.5.2.3.2 Corrective Action for Aggregate Quality
If the result of a quality test fails to meet the requirements for quality
during submittal of samples for mixture-proportioning studies or
immediately prior to start of concrete placement, production procedures or
materials must be changed and additional tests must be performed until the
material meets the quality requirements prior to proceeding with either
mixture-proportioning studies or starting concrete placement. After
concrete placement commences, whenever the result of a test for quality
fails the requirements, the test must be rerun immediately. If the second
test fails the quality requirement, the fact must be reported to the CO and
immediate steps taken to rectify the situation.
3.5.2.4 Compressive Strength Testing
At least one set of test specimens will be made each day on each different
mixture placed during each shift. Additional sets of test cylinders will
be made, as directed by the CO, when the mixture proportions are changed or
when low strengths have been detected. A random sampling plan will be
developed and approved by the CO prior to the start of construction.
Sampling must be random in accordance with the requirements of ASTM D3665.
A set of test specimens for concrete with a 90-day strength will consist of
six cylinders, two tested at seven days, two at 28 days, and two at 90 days.
Test specimens will be 6 inch diameter by 12 inches, molded in accordance
with ASTM C1176/1176M or ASTM C1435/C1435M, protected and cured in
accordance with ASTM C31/C31M, and tested in accordance with ASTM C39/C39M.
All compressive-strength tests will be reported immediately to the CO.
Quality control charts must be kept for individual strength tests, moving
average for strength, and moving average for range for each mixture. The
charts must be similar to those found in ACI 214R.
3.5.2.5 Vebe Consistency
For each set of strength specimens as described above a Vebe Consistency in
accordance with ASTM C1170/C1170M must be completed. Both the Vebe time
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 38
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
and Density must be reported as part of the Contractor's Quality Control
Program.
3.5.2.6 Scales
3.5.2.6.1 Weighing Accuracy
The accuracy of the scales must be checked by test weights at least once a
month for conformance with the applicable requirements of paragraphs BATCH
PLANT and CONTINUOUS MIXING PLANT both in PART 2. Such tests must also be
made as directed whenever there are variations in properties of the fresh
concrete that could result from batching errors.
3.5.2.6.2 Batching and Recording Accuracy
Once a week the accuracy of each batching and recording device must be
checked during a weighing operation by noting and recording the required
weight, recorded weight, and the actual weight batched. Confirm that the
calibration devices described in paragraph BATCH PLANT in PART 2 for
checking the accuracy of dispensed admixtures are operating properly. If a
continuous mixing plant is provided, the accuracy and operation of all
feeding and dispensing units must be checked before the start of operation
each day.
3.5.2.6.3 Scales Corrective Action
When the weighing accuracy or batching accuracy does not comply with
specification requirements, the plant must not be operated until necessary
adjustments or repairs have been made. Discrepancies in recording
accuracies must be corrected immediately.
3.5.2.7 Concrete Plant Control
The measurement of all constituent materials including cementitious
materials, each size of aggregate, water, and admixtures must be
continuously controlled. The aggregate weights and amount of added water
must be adjusted as necessary to compensate for free moisture in the
aggregates. A report must be prepared indicating type and source of cement
used, type and source of pozzolan or slag used, amount and source of
admixtures used, aggregate source, the required aggregate and water weights
per cubic yard, amount of water as free moisture in each size of aggregate,
and the as-mixed aggregate and water weights per cubic yard for each class
of concrete placed during plant operation.
3.5.2.8 Field Density
3.5.2.8.1 Testing and Checking
Density must be determined for at least eight locations per RCC lift with a
calibrated nuclear density gauge in accordance with ASTM C1040/C1040M.
Densities must be taken at depths of 4 and 8 inches. If the densities at 4
and 8 inches conflict, acceptance must be at the 8 inch depth.
3.5.2.8.2 Action Required
Whenever the nuclear gauge indicates density less than the specified
density, a retest must be made. If the retest indicates unacceptable
density, the CO's Representative must be notified, additional rolling must
be immediately provided, and a determination must be made as to whether the
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 39
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
lower density resulted from insufficient passes of the roller or a change
in the mix properties. If the mix properties have changed, adjustments
such as increasing or decreasing the moisture content must be made at the
batch plant. If the problem persists, the CO may adjust the proportions of
aggregates, cement, and pozzolan. If the lower density is the result of
incomplete rolling, the operator must be notified and the CO may require
removal of the incompletely compacted material at no cost to the Government.
3.5.2.9 Inspection Before Placing
Foundation or construction joints, forms, and embedded items must be
inspected in sufficient time prior to each concrete placement to certify to
the CO that they are ready to receive concrete. The results of each
inspection must be reported in writing. The inspection of the lift
surfaces of the RCC will be a continuing activity and must be accomplished
in accordance with paragraph REGULAR LIFT-JOINT TREATMENT above.
3.5.2.10 Placing Inspection
3.5.2.10.1 Inspection
Provide full time supervision of all placing operations to insure that the
correct quality of RCC, conventional concrete, or grout is placed in each
location and that all other aspects of the placing operation are performed
in accordance with the Contract. During placing operations, the quality
control staff must measure and record concrete temperatures in accordance
with ASTM C1064/C1064M, ambient temperature hourly, record weather
conditions, time of placement, yardage placed, and method of placement.
3.5.2.10.2 Corrective Action
The placing foreman must not permit placing to begin until he has verified
that an adequate number of vibrators, spreaders, and compactors in working
order and with competent operators are available. Placing must not be
continued if any conventional concrete is inadequately consolidated or if
any lift of RCC is not fully compacted. Additional compaction, if
necessary, must be performed in accordance with paragraph ADDITIONAL
COMPACTION above. If any batch of conventional concrete fails to meet the
temperature requirements, immediate steps must be taken to improve
temperature controls.
3.5.2.11 Vibrator Tests
3.5.2.11.1 Vibrator Testing and Use
The frequency and amplitude of each vibrator must be determined in
accordance with COE CRD-C 521 prior to initial use and at least once a
month when concrete is being placed. Additional tests must be made as
directed when a vibrator does not appear to be adequately consolidating the
concrete. The frequency must be determined while the vibrator is operating
in concrete with the tachometer being held against the upper end of the
vibrator head while almost submerged and just before the vibrator is
withdrawn from the concrete. The amplitude must be determined with the
head vibrating in air. Two measurements must be taken, one near the tip
and another near the upper end of the vibrator head, and these results
averaged. The make, model, type, and size of the vibrator and frequency
and amplitude results must be reported in writing. In addition, the
self-propelled vibratory rollers, as specified in PART 2, paragraph PRIMARY
ROLLERS, must be checked for frequency and amplitude prior to use and once
SECTION 03 37 23.00 25 Page 40
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
every three months when RCC is being placed.
3.5.2.11.2 Vibrator Corrective Action
Any vibrator not meeting the requirements of paragraph VIBRATORS must be
immediately removed from service and repaired or replaced.
3.5.2.12 Curing Inspection
3.5.2.12.1 Moist Curing Inspections
At least twice each shift, and twice per day on nonwork days an inspection
must be made of all areas subject to moist curing. The surface moisture
condition must be noted and recorded.
3.5.2.12.2 Moist Curing Corrective Action
When a daily inspection report lists an area of inadequate curing,
immediate corrective action must be taken, and the required curing period
for those areas must be extended by one day.
3.5.2.13 Cold-Weather and Hot-Weather Protection
At least once each shift and once per day on nonwork days an inspection
must be made of all areas subject to cold-weather or hot-weather
protection. Any deficiencies must be noted, corrected, and reported.
3.5.2.14 Cold-Weather and Hot-Weather Protection Corrective Action
When a daily inspection report lists deficiencies, the deficiency must be
corrected immediately and the period of protection extended for one day.
3.5.3 Reports
All results of tests or inspections conducted must be reported informally
as they are completed and in writing daily. A weekly report must be
prepared for the updating of control charts covering the entire period from
the start of the construction season through the current week. During
periods of cold-weather protection, reports of pertinent temperatures must
be made daily. These requirements do not relieve the Contractor of the
obligation to report certain failures immediately as required in preceding
paragraphs. Such reports of failures and the action taken must be
confirmed in writing in the routine reports. The CO has the right to
examine all Contractor quality control records.

1.2 SUMMARY
This Section specifies ready-mix Controlled Low Strength Material (CLSM)
for the following applications:
Filling of the 30 pipes and entire valve pit located in the Outlet
Works structure to be abandoned.
1.3 DEFINITIONS
a. Ready-mix CLSM is used for utility pipe backfill, and is also known
as controlled density fill or flowable fill as defined in ACI 229R.
CLSM differs from Portland cement concrete as it contains a low
cementitious content to reduce strength development for possible future
removal. Chemical admixtures may also be used in CLSM to modify
performance properties of strength, flow, set and hydraulic
conductivity. Pumpable mixes are available.
b. CLSM must have compressive strength properties per Paragraph MIX
COMPRESSIVE STRENGTH below.
1.4 SUBMITTALS

submittals not having a "G" designation are for information only. When
used, a designation following the "G" designation identifies the office
that will review the submittal for the Government. Submit the following in
accordance with Section 01 33 00, SUBMITTAL PROCEDURES:

MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
CLSM Truck Mix Revolutions; G
1.5 QUALITY ASSURANCE
1.5.1 Manufacturer
CLSM must be manufactured by a ready-mix concrete producer with a minimum
of one year experience in the production of similar products.
1.6 DELIVERY, STORAGE, AND HANDLING
Deliver and handle in strict compliance with manufacturer's
recommendations. Protect from damage due to weather, excessive
temperatures, and construction operations.
1.7 MIXING AND TRANSPORTING
Batching, mixing, and delivery of CLSM must conform to the applicable
provisions of ASTM C94/C94M. CLSM must be placed within one and a half
hours of addition of water to the dry ingredients. Truck mixed CLSM must
have undergone a minimum of 100 and maximum of 300 drum revolutions prior
to placement. The Contractor may not add water to the mix after initial
batching and transport. Submit a CLSM Truck Mix Revolutions report.
1.8 PROJECT CONDITIONS
Perform work only when existing and forecasted weather conditions are
within the limits established by the manufacturer of the materials and
products used.
PART 2 PRODUCTS
2.1 MANUFACTURER
2.1.1 CLSM
Provide CLSM manufactured by a ready-mix concrete producer experienced in
the design and control of flowable mixtures. Manufacturer must provide
mixtures meeting performance properties specified herein.
2.2 MATERIALS
2.2.1 Portland Cement
Portland Cement: ASTM C150/C150M, Type II.
2.2.2 Blended Cements
Blended hydraulic cement must conform to ASTM C595/C595M.
2.2.3 Aggregate
Provide fine aggregate material meeting the requirements of ASTM C33/C33M.
2.2.4 Other Admixtures
Provide material meeting the requirements of ASTM C494/C494M.
SECTION 03 52 01.00 25 Page 4
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
2.2.5 Pozzolanic Materials
Fly ash meeting ASTM C618, Class F requirements.
2.3 CLSM
2.3.1 Mix Design
Mix design must produce a consistency that will result in a flowable
product at the time of placement which does not require manual means to
move it into place. Admixtures proposed for use must be evaluated in the
mix design. A Mix design for the Controlled Low Strength Material (CLSM)
must be submitted.
2.3.2 Mix Compressive Strength
Provide mix with compressive strength of minimum 100 psi according to
ASTM D4832 and ACI 229R at 28 days after placement.
2.3.3 Final Bleeding
CLSM must have minimal subsidence and bleed water which is measured as a
Final Bleeding of less than 2.0 percent (retains 98.0 percent of original
height after placement, approximately 1/4 inch per foot of depth) per
ASTM C940.
2.3.4 Fresh Unit Weight
The fresh unit weight must be 100 - 120 lbs/ft3, except where otherwise
specified.
2.3.5 CLSM Consistency
The consistency of the CLSM slurry must be such that the material flows and
completely fills the pipes.
2.3.6 Slump
The slump of CLSM must have a slump cone value or lateral spread test of at
least 8 inches as determined in general accordance with ASTM D6103/D6103M
or ASTM C143/C143M respectively.
PART 3 EXECUTION
3.1 EXAMINATION
Examine conditions of substrates and other conditions under which work is
to be performed and notify the Government, in writing, of circumstances
detrimental to the proper completion of the work. Do not proceed until
unsatisfactory conditions are corrected.

Contractor during the placement of the CLSM as follows:

RIVER DIVERSION
PART 1 GENERAL
1.1 GENERAL INFORMATION
This Section covers river diversion during construction. The exact methods
for river diversion are not specified. The river diversion methods are the
responsibility of the Contractor. Follow the performance requirements
specified in this Section for river diversion.
1.2 SUBMITTALS
Government approval is required for submittals with a "G" designation;
submittals not having a "G" designation are for information only. Submit
the following in accordance with Section 01 33 00, SUBMITTAL PROCEDURES:
SD-01 Preconstruction Submittals
River Diversion Plan; G
SD-05 Design Data
Cofferdam Design; G
SD-06 Test Reports
River Diversion Report
1.3 FLOW DATA
a. Attachment A6, shows daily average discharge curves for various
exceedance values. Discharge data for USGS gage 14240525, NF Toutle
River Below SRS Near Kid Valley, WA, can be found here:
http://waterdata.usgs.gov/nwis/uv?14240525.
b. The Northwest River Forecast Center provides flow forecasts for the
main stem Toutle River at the Tower Road bridge. These forecasts can
be found at the following location:
http://www.nwrfc.noaa.gov/river/station/flowplot/flowplot.cgi?TOTW1.
c. Significant rainfall-runoff driven flow events are rare during the
in-water-work-period, but they have occurred within the gage record.
The river forecast can be one way of staying informed if flows are
expected to change. Be aware that forecast data is uncertain and may
under or over predict flows or potentially miss an event entirely. If
a rainfall event occurs, a change in flow and water surface elevation
will likely follow shortly.
1.4 RIVER DIVERSION PLAN
Submit a River Diversion Plan. Submit 30 days prior to start of river
diversion work. Describe the Contractor's river diversion system for the
duration of the project, including, as a minimum: cofferdams, culverts, and
SECTION 30 00 01.00 25 Page 2
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
other river diversion features; the discharge of the North Fork Toutle
River that the river diversion system is designed to accommodate without
flooding the worksite; potential seepage and methods that will be used to
handle such seepage; methods for maintaining the minimum discharge for
river continuity; methods for maintaining the minimum flow depth; and a
statement of concurrence with the River Diversion Plan by the Contractor's
professional engineer. In addition, include drawings and figures to
illustrate the plan visually. If the Contractor elects to install culverts
within the RCC structure, include in the River Diversion Plan all aspects
of the activity, including the type(s) of culverts, the plan for
installation, and the plan for filling with concrete upon completion of
use. A Construction photo of the temporary works developed in 2012 is
included in Drawing C-008 Care and Diversion of Water During Construction.
The drawing illustrates areas that can be used for diversion and those that
cannot.
1.5 PROFESSIONAL ENGINEER
A registered professional engineer must design the river diversion system.
The professional engineer must concur with the River Diversion Plan. The
professional engineer must inspect the river diversion system during
initial construction, whenever there is a change in configuration, and
during high river flow events. The professional engineer must produce a
River Diversion Report for each site visit documenting all observations,
recommendations, and updates to the river diversion system. The
professional engineer must be available to meet with the Contracting
Officer at any time throughout the Contract duration. Update the River
Diversion Plan and re-submit with any changes. Submit no later than one
day after each site visit by professional engineer.
PART 2 PRODUCTS
Not Used.
PART 3 EXECUTION
3.1 COFFERDAMS AND CULVERTS
a. The Contractor may construct cofferdams and use culverts as
necessary for the river diversion system. As a minimum, the river
diversion system must be capable of passing a river discharge of 860
cubic feet per second without flooding the worksite. This flow has a
10 percent chance of exceedance in any given year between July 1 to
September 30. Extending the work any later would likely experience
increased flows and affect the Contractor's design.
b. The Contractor is allowed to install steel or concrete culverts
within the RCC structure, for the purpose of river diversion, as long
as the following requirements are met:
(1) The culverts are strong enough to support the loads from the
RCC structure during the river diversion time period.
(2) No RCC compacted against the culverts below their springline.
(3) Place a minimum of two feet of conventional concrete, with a
compressive strength no less than 3,000 pounds per square inch,
around the culverts below their springline.
SECTION 30 00 01.00 25 Page 3
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
(4) Culverts are anchored down to prevent flotation during
concrete placement below the springline.
(5) Upon completion of the river diversion time period, completely
fill all culverts installed within the RCC structure with concrete
with compressive strength of no less than 3,000 pounds per square
inch.
c. The existing outlet works pipes may not be used for river
diversion. River diversion must occur within the existing spillway
channel.
d. Cofferdams must be designed by a licensed professional engineer in
the State of Washington. Cofferdams must be designed according to
USACE manuals and regulations cited in the Paragraph REFERENCES.
Submit cofferdam design for review. Submit at least 30 days prior to
IWW for review. Include all relevant sketches, shop drawings, and
calculations packages. Designs must be peer reviewed by an independent
technical reviewer with supporting documentation of that review
provided in the package. Cofferdams designed and constructed as part
of temporary works must have any features not consisting of earth
materials removed from the spillway and sediment plain.
3.2 SEEPAGE
Consider the potential for seepage through cofferdams and through the rock
foundation beneath cofferdams. Design the river diversion system to
prevent potential seepage from disrupting construction activities, by
minimizing or collecting such potential seepage.
3.3 MINIMUM DISCHARGE FOR RIVER CONTINUITY
During transitions in river diversions, maintain a minimum discharge of 50
cubic feet per second of the North Fork Toutle River from the upstream
reservoir to the downstream channel. The location of the discharge along
the existing spillway crest may vary during construction. Measure the
discharge in the North Fork Toutle River at the USGS gage 14240525 located
at the Fish Collection Facility downstream of the Sediment Retention
Structure. Pumping water for river diversion is not allowed in order to
protect any fish that may be migrating downstream while the river diversion
system is in place. During this minimum discharge, the number of culvert
pipes may need to be limited to assure minimum depth criteria (next
paragraph) is met.
3.4 MINIMUM FLOW DEPTH
Except for transitions described above, maintain a discharge of 340 cfs and
a minimum flow depth of one foot to provide passage for any fish that may
be migrating downstream while the Contractor's river diversion system is in
place. A siphon is an acceptable method to pass fish and water.
Contractor may cut slots through the RCC baffles of the first raise for
pipe access. The combination of number and size of pipes must not cause
the flow depths to run below minimum depth in the pipes at the median
discharge 340 cfs during construction season.
3.5 DIVERSION CONNECTIVITY TO EXISTING LOW FLOW CHANNEL
The river flows down the existing seven foot RCC crest raise wedge to the
existing excavated low channel. No flow must be diverted southwest of the
SECTION 30 00 01.00 25 Page 4
MSH SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTURE CREST RAISE
dashed line (i.e. No Diversion Area) shown on the Contract Drawings
(C-007). Any means of piping, channeling, or berm is acceptable as long as
there is no stranding of the fish. Clearance of woody vegetation along the
conveyance route is required.
3.6 FISH RESCUE
Provide Fisheries Biologists or Biological Technicians during construction
of the coffer dam and river division to rescue and relocate any stranded
fish. Any stranded fish will be rescued immediately and returned directly
back into the river.
3.7 DEMOBILIZATION
Prior to demobilization from the site, all man-made components of the river
diversion system must be removed and must remain the property of the
Contractor. Earth materials used in cofferdams may remain in place,
however, cofferdam material above the elevation of the crest of the low
flow channel must be removed.
