16.7 Hold Orders.
 16.7.1 Only applies for BPA work. Corps employees are not authorized to work under HOLD
ORDERS.
 16.7.2 This procedure is for Transmission lines only.
16.7.3 The line remains energized when a Hold Order is in place.
16.7.4 HOLD ORDER - Assurance given to a worker by a System Dispatcher or Substation
Operator that if a transmission line is de-energized, (for any reason) it will not be ordered
energized until that worker reports the crew in the clear.
16.7.5 TERMINAL HOLD - is a formal assurance of non-reclosure at the Local Terminal or
Terminals of an inter-connecting circuit provided by the Local System Dispatcher (or
powerhouse Operator) to a requesting Dispatcher. The Terminal Hold assures the
requesting Dispatcher that the terminal or source on “Hold” has sufficient relays in service
to provide protection in the event of a fault; and, once tripped out of service, will not be
energized, automatically or manually until the Dispatcher receiving the Terminal Hold has
advised that all personnel and materials are in the clear and it is safe to energize.

16.7.5.1 A Hold Order is given on the entire line. A Terminal Hold is only given to a
Dispatcher or PH Operator from one end and is used in conjunction with other tagging
to issue a Hold on the entire line to a worker.
 16.7.6 A clearance is used in place of a Hold order for Corps personnel.
16.7.7 Hold Order Procedure:
16.7.7.1 Scheduled through Operations Manager.
16.7.7.2 The II can schedule Terminal Hold Orders if the Operations Manager is not available.

16.7.7.3 II/DRII hangs the “HOLD ORDER” on all Control Points. Tags shall be placed on all
control points including GDACS screens. This includes any station service feed on the

16.7.7.4 BPA’s dispatcher will coordinate with the II.

Order in place by _______.”
16.7.7.11 When releasing a Hold Order:

17.0 Unattended or Remote Stations
17.1 The II controls the proper clearing, locking and tagging of equipment in accordance with
HEC procedures. In an emergency, the RO may designate the same person to fill the role of
both DRII and PAI/AI.
17.2 The II shall be notified immediately prior to and upon completion of the switching/clearing
operations.
17.3 The PAI/AI requesting the Safe Clearance shall place isolation locks to secure each energy
isolation device and initial each isolation point tag upon verification of that device’s proper
position and condition.
17.4 The PAI shall review and test the new isolation with the APs per 11.5.6 or 19.7 and 19.8 for
contractors.
17.5 After completion of the work, the II shall be informed of the time the Safe Clearance was released.
17.6 The II shall enter the following info in the Station Logbook: Safe Clearance number; date and
military time of release; and names of individuals issuing and receiving the release authorization.
Upon releasing a Safe Clearance, the word “RELEASED” shall be written or stamped across the
corresponding log entries in a distinct color.
17.7 Retain Safe Clearance documentation for a minimum of two years from the date of release.

18.0 Caution Orders
18.1 Caution Orders shall be reviewed by the RO or their designee at least every six months to ensure
the caution order is still needed. If used for more than one year, the caution order shall be
removed and operating procedures shall be developed to reflect current operational conditions.
18.2 Caution orders shall not be used to protect personnel.
18.3 Caution orders must be approved and documented by the II.
18.4 Caution orders are issued with direct attention to abnormal or unusual conditions, or to special
operating instructions to be followed.
18.5 Each caution order shall be assigned an identification number.
18.6 Caution orders will be logged in the station logbook.
18.7 ENG Form 1928, “Caution Order” Sheet, will be prepared for each caution order issued. This will
supplement the Station Logbook entry at those projects maintaining Station Logbooks and provide
the necessary project records at other projects. Records shall be maintained for a minimum of two
years.
18.8 ENG Form 1924, Caution Order Tag, will be properly completed and attached to appropriate
control devices and equipment.
19.0 Additional Items Concerning Contractors or Non-Project Personnel
19.1 SAF 385-1 shall be used for lockout/tag out of all equipment connected to government-owned
equipment. An approved contractor HECP can be used in addition to, but never in lieu of, the Corps
of Engineers HECP.
19.2 When USACE employees are on a site that is controlled by a contractor and are affected by the
contractor-managed HECP, they shall comply with the contractors HECP. The Contractors HECP
shall be developed IAW 29 CFR 1910.147, ANSI Z244.1, and ANSI A10.44.
19.3 When non-project personnel perform construction or maintenance at government-operated facilities
and are exposed to hazardous energy, the non-project personnel shall also be trained in and
protected by SAF 385-1.
A10-39
CENWP-OD-SAF-385-1
CENWP-OD Standing Safety Procedure 385-1
SAFETY
Portland District Supplement to USACE Hazardous
Energy Control Program
Portland District
Current Approved Version 18 Jan 2020). Printed copies are for “Information Only.” The controlled version resides on the CENWPOD SharePoint portal, Libraries at: https://intranet.usace.army.mil/nwd/nwp/od/pages/home.aspx
19.4 If a non-USACE entity desires to implement their HEC procedure in addition to SAF 385-1, the
non-USACE entity shall implement their HEC procedure in coordination with the local Issuing
Individual. The non-USACE entity will provide their HEC program and procedures to the
Government Designated Authority (GDA) as a submittal, which must be accepted by the GDA
prior to beginning work.
19.4.1 At a minimum, Contractors shall submit a letter of acknowledgment and compliance to
the Portland District HEC Program, CENWP-OD-SAF-385-1 (2019) to the GDA prior
to beginning work.
19.5 When Safe Clearances are required to safely perform the work, the PAI will discuss the HEC
Program requirements with the non-project representative to ensure they understand the hazards,
procedures, and limits of the Safe Clearance. The non-project representative shall review the plan
for accomplishing the work with the PAI in such detail as may be necessary for them to determine
the hazardous energy isolation boundaries.
19.6 Requests for USACE Safe Clearances.
19.6.1 The request shall be made with sufficient information and advanced notice to ensure that
the PAI can accommodate the request. The request must be made in writing, electronic
mail is an acceptable written format. The written request must include the following
information:
x Contract number
x Contractor name
x Specific equipment and locations of work to be performed so that appropriate clearance
boundaries can be identified by the PAI/II
x Date and time of the requested outage
x Duration of outage
x Description of work to be performed in sufficient detail for the PAI/II to determine
appropriate clearance points
x Activity / Job Hazard Analysis (AHA/JHA) for work to be completed under outage; the
AHA is considered a living document, as work progresses additional AHAs or
revisions may be necessary to capture work progression, these shall be submitted by
A10-40
CENWP-OD-SAF-385-1
CENWP-OD Standing Safety Procedure 385-1
SAFETY
Portland District Supplement to USACE Hazardous

Portland District

the Contractor and approved by the GDA prior to commencing new work; the GDA
will not approve new work under an existing clearance until the clearance boundary
has been confirmed as adequate. The Construction Branch is responsible for and
approves AHAs for contract work. Reference 10.1 for additional information regarding
AHA requirements.
x The name of the non-project representative who will be responsible for the work and
safety of the job.
19.6.2 All clearance requests must be made at least 24 hours in advance.
19.6.2.1 Clearance requests involving a generator unit outage require written requests at
least 45 days prior to the Monday of the week the outage is to occur.
 19.6.2.2 Clearance requests involving line outages require written requests at least 75
days prior to the month the outage is to occur.
19.7 The PAI holding the Safe Clearance shall review with the superintendent/work leader the limits of
the de-energized and isolated working area, including any unusual conditions. This review will
occur at the work site after the clearance is in place and will include a review of the limits of the deenergized and isolated working area, AHA, isolation points, work to be completed, and unusual
conditions. Upon request, the PAI holding the Safe Clearance will walk the isolation as part of the
review, review any associated drawings, hand over hand the system, and/or provide the station
O&M manual.
19.7.1 Each AP is responsible for reviewing the clearance with the PAI or Superintendent/work
leader prior to signing on to the Safe Clearance. This review will occur at the work site and
will include a review of the limits of the de-energized and isolated working area, AHA,
isolation points, work to be completed, and any unusual conditions. Upon the request of any
AP signing onto the clearance, the PAI holding the Safe Clearance will walk the isolation as
part of the review, review associated drawings, hand over hand the system, and/or provide
the station O&M manual.
19.7.2 A PAI cannot authorize a Superintendent/Work Leader to sign on to a clearance via
telephone or radio.
19.7.3 Each Affected Person working under the group clearance shall sign the Safe Clearance Sign
in Sheet verifying he or she fully understands the details of their job, the energy isolation
devices actuated, the locks and tags installed, and will then place their personal lock on the
group lockbox.

Current Approved Version 18 Jan 2020). Printed copies are for “Information Only.” The controlled version resides on the CENWPOD SharePoint portal, Libraries at: https://intranet.usace.army.mil/nwd/nwp/od/pages/home.aspx
19.8 After the Safe Clearance is issued, the PAI and the first AP signing onto the clearance shall inspect
and test the work site to verify the adequacy of the protection provided. The first AP shall concur
with the method of inspection and be qualified to perform the testing.
19.8.1 The method of testing shall be described on the specific AHA for the associated clearance.
Only the first AP to sign onto the clearance is required to test for the absence of hazardous
energy with the PAI. The AP and PAI who perform the verification/testing shall sign and
record this on the Safe Clearance Order.
19.8.2 The PAI and/or AP, by signing either the Safe Clearance Order form or Safe Clearance
Activity Log confirming the absence of hazardous energy, are acknowledging that
verification/testing has been performed as described in the AHA or Activity Log and no
hazardous energy was detected as of the date and time of their signature
19.8.3 The method of testing for isolation points added after the clearance is accepted, or re-hung
after a temporary lift, will be described on the Safe Clearance Activity Log.
19.8.4 No other APs shall sign onto the Safe Clearance sign-in sheet prior to confirming the
completion of the verification/testing documentation.
19.8.5 Other APs are required to confirm the verification/testing has been completed by
observation of the AP’s signature on the Safe Clearance order. If isolation points have been
temp lifted and restored, confirmation of the testing signature is recorded on the Safe
Clearance Activity sheet.
 19.8.6 APs other than the first APs to sign onto the clearance may test the isolation provided it
poses no risk to APs already working at the job site protected by the clearance. For
example, testing for voltage with a voltmeter doesn’t add additional risk to AP’s already
working on the circuit. Attempting to open a spill gate while other APs are working below
it does increase the risk of danger to APs working below the spill gate.
 19.8.7 Work that requires electrical energy to be isolated shall be made electrically safe via a Safe
Clearance and tested as follows:
 19.8.7.1 An adequately rated test instrument will be used to test each phase conductor or
circuit part to verify it is de-energized.
 19.8.7.2 Test each phase conductor or circuit part both phase-to-phase and phase-toground.
 19.8.7.3 Before and after each test, determine that the test instrument is operating

satisfactorily through verification on a known voltage source.
19.9 Upon completion of work, the PAI shall concur with non-project personnel that the equipment is
ready to be returned to service or commissioned.
19.10 All Contractor employees involved in any HEC Program are required to complete the USACE
Portland District HECP Training. Training must be completed annually. Each employee must have
an up to date certificate when working under a clearance.
20.0 Non-Standard Maintenance.
20.1 Non-standard equipment is that which is not directly associated with the generation of hydropower or the flow of water from Portland District Projects. Such equipment includes but is not
limited to elevators, escalators, hoists, and other such equipment which require being energized
to perform certain required maintenance functions.
2 0 . 2 When manufacturer’s specifications and/or industry- recognized governing standards (e.g. ANSI
and ASME) define the operation, inspection, testing, and maintenance of specific equipment
the specification or governing standard may be used in lieu of the district HECP unless
otherwise directed by the RO or his designated representative.
21.0 Abnormal Release and Removal
21.1 Abnormal Removal of Personal Locks. When the individual who applied a personal lock is not
available to remove it due to extraordinary circumstances, the individual’s immediate supervisor
shall assume full responsibility for the removal of the personal lock after performing the following
actions.
21.1.1Verify that the individual who applied the personal lock is not at the facility.
21.1.2 Make all reasonable efforts to contact the individual to inform them that their personal
lock will be removed.
21.1.3 Ensure that the individual will be informed of the removal before they resume work
at that facility by signing the Abnormal Removal of Personal Lock Form.
21.1.4 Obtain written authorization from the RO or their Designee to remove the individual’s
personal lock.
A10-43
CENWP-OD-SAF-385-1
CENWP-OD Standing Safety Procedure 385-1
SAFETY
Portland District Supplement to USACE Hazardous
Energy Control Program
Portland District
Current Approved Version 18 Jan 2020). Printed copies are for “Information Only.” The controlled version resides on the CENWPOD SharePoint portal, Libraries at: https://intranet.usace.army.mil/nwd/nwp/od/pages/home.aspx
21.1.5 Documentation provided in the Abnormal Removal of Personal Lock Form must be filled
in and attached to the Safe Clearance as a permanent record of the action.
21.2 Abnormal Release of a Safe Clearance. When, due to extraordinary circumstances, it is not
possible for the PAI/AI to release the Safe Clearance, the PAI/AI’s Immediate Supervisor shall
assume full responsibility for the release of the Safe Clearance and removal of their personal
lock after performing the following actions.
21.2.1 Verify that the PAI/AI who holds the Safe Clearance and applied their personal lock
onto the lockbox is not at the facility.
21.2.2 Make all reasonable efforts to contact the PAI/AI to inform them that their Safe
Clearance and personal lock will be removed.
21.2.3 Ensure that the PAI/AI will be informed of the removal before they resume work at that
facility by signing the Abnormal Release of Safe Clearance Form.
21.2.4 Obtain written authorization from the RO or their designee to release the Safe Clearance
and remove the PAI/AI’s personal lock.
21.2.5 Inspected the work area to assure non-essential items/tools have been removed from the
system and the system components are operationally intact.
21.2.6 Verify TPGs have been released.
21.2.7 Ensure all personnel have signed off the Safe Clearance Sign-In Sheet and have removed
their personal locks from the lockbox.
21.2.8 Documentation provided in the Abnormal Release of Safe Clearance Form must be filled in
and attached to the Safe Clearance as a permanent record of the action.
22.0 Records and Measurements
22.1 All training records, clearance forms, AHAs, and work permits shall be kept on file for a minimum of
two years. Self-assessment/inspection reports shall be kept on file for a minimum of five years.

23.0 Inspection and Program Review
23.1 Periodic inspections shall be designed and conducted to ensure all requirements of the
HEC Program are being followed, to identify and correct any weaknesses (or potential
weaknesses) in the program or procedures, in employee training, or in how the
requirements are enforced. See Attachment 7.
23.2 The Responsible Official shall ensure the periodic inspections are performed.
23.3 Periodic inspections shall be performed at least annually by individual(s)
knowledgeable in HEC Program and Procedures, to include a Qualified Person.
Personnel internal to the facility may conduct the inspection one year and personnel
external to the facility shall conduct the inspection the next year (peer review). The
person using the HEC procedure cannot inspect the procedure.
23.4 Periodic inspections of HEC procedures shall cover at least one lockout/tag out without a
clearance and a safe clearance in progress, the procedure details and include a review
between the inspectors and individuals involved in the safe clearance being inspected.
23.5 Inspections shall be documented (date, persons involved, results) and identified
deficiencies noted. Corrective actions taken to improve the program or employee
knowledge of the program must include how any revision of specific procedures or a
general change is communicated to the workers.

A10-77
Attachment 8: Self Inspection Checklist
Portland District Hazardous Energy Control Program Self Inspection Checklist
References refer to: ER 385-1-31 The Control of Hazardous Energy 1 NOV 2009 YES NO N/A
ITEM Please use your initials to mark
these columns
1. Has the Responsible Official (RO) established a HEC Program at their respective Project?
2. Has the RO designated in writing the occupants and responsibilities of the following positions:
ER 385-1-31, 2-2c
a. Issuing Individual (II)?
b. Designated Representative to the Issuing Individual (DRll)?
c. Principal Authorized Individual (PAI)?
d. Authorized individual(s) (Al)?
3. Has the RO designated in writing any special conditions at the project?
4. Has the RO established a Safe Clearance Committee to evaluate the HECP:
ER 385-1-31, 11-1
5. Is the HECP reviewed (evaluated) and updated annually?
6. Does the Project perform annual inspections of their HECP procedures? ER 385-1-31,11-3
a. Do these inspections include a safe clearance in progress? ER 385-1-31, 11-4
b. Do these inspections include one lockout/tag out without a safe clearance? ER 385-1-31, 11-4
c. Do these inspections include a review of the procedural details? ER 385-1-31, 11-4
d. Do these inspections include a review between the inspector and the individuals involved in the safe clearance
Do these inspections document (date, persons involved, results) and identify deficiencies
f. Are inspection results forwarded to the RO?
g. Is the inspection documentation kept for a minimum of five (5) years?
7. Is Project documentation available to all persons involved with issuing and holding safe clearances?
ER 385-1-31, 2-2.I

8. Does the Project HEC training program require initial, annual, and as-required retraining? ER 385-1-31, 2
a. Does annual retraining include a written assessment? ER 385-1-31,
b. Is training documentation maintained on file for at least two (2) years? ER 385-1-31, 5-2
c. Is retraining conducted when there is an unauthorized deviation from HEC procedures, demonstrated lack of employee
knowledge, change in assignment, change in hazards, or change in the HECP? ER 385-1-31, 5-4.b and c

9. Are training records, clearance logs, forms, work permits, inspections reports kept for a minimum of 2 years? ER 385-1-31
10. Does the Issuing Individual direct the switching/clearing and related operations needed to place and remove clearances
11. Does the Issuing Individual accept and release safe clearances for the following conditions:
a. Line terminal clearances on tie lines?
b. Supply lines to and from outside utilities/agencies?

Notes:
1. C&D materials are those generated by construction, renovation, repair, and demolition activities.
2. Destination is the name of the facility to which C&D materials were transported.
3. Recycled includes materials sent to a recycling facility.
4. Composted includes any vegetational material sent to a recycling/composting facility.
5. Converted includes waste that was converted into an energy use (e.g. waste converted to heat, electricity, or fuel).
6. Landfilled includes any C&D waste that is landfilled or incinerated at a landfill facility.
7. Total costs of all disposal methods.
